In ancient times in the region of Chuan,
the Nan-cheng Chung was ordered to take charge of the affairs of heaven,
while the Pei-cheng Li took charge of those of earth.
In the reigns of T'ang and Yü [i.e.,Yao an Shun]
the descendants of Chung and Li
were reestablished as the managers of the affairs of heaven and earth.
During the Hsia and Shang dynasties
these same Chung and Li families continued generation after generation to manage the affairs of heaven and earth.
The earl og Ch'eng Hsiu Fu in the Chou dynasty,
was their descendant.
In the time of King Hsian of the Chou [827-781 B.C.]
the family lost its position and became the Ssu-ma family.
The Ssu-ma family for generations had charge of the historical records of the chou.
In the time of Kings Hui and Hsiang [676-618 B.C.]
the Ssu-ma family left Chou and went to Chin.
When the general of the Central Army, Sui Hui of Chin, fled to Ch'in,
the Ssu-ma family moved to Shao-liang.
From the time the Ssu-ma family left Chou and went to Chin,
they became broken up and scattered,
some live in Wei,
some in Chao,
and some in Ch'in.
From the branch of the family in Wei
came the Prime Minister of Chung-shan.
The branch of the family in Chao
was famous as hereditary masters of the art of swordsmanship.
K'uai-wai was a descendant of this branch.
In the Ch'in branch there was a there was a Ssu-ma named Ts'o, who argued his opinions with Chang I.
Thereupon King Hui sent Ts'o to lead an army against Shu.
After subduing it
he remained to guard his conquest.
Ts'o's grandson Chin
served the Lord of Wu-an, Po Ch'i.
The name of Shao-liang was changed to Hsia-yang. Chin an the lord of Wu-an attacked the army of Chao
at Ch'ang-p'ing.
After their return to Ch'in they were both ordered to die at Tu-yu.
They were buried at Hua-ch'ih.
Chin's grandson was Ch'ang.
Ch'ang was head of a Bureau of Iron
under the Ch'in dynasty.
In the time of the First Emperor of Ch'in [221-210 B.C.] K'uai-wai's great-great-grandson Ang served as general to the Lord of Wu-hsin, garrisoning Ch'ao-ko.
When the various feudal lords were being made kings,
Hsiang Yü made Ang the king of Yin.
When the Han forces attacked Ch'u [i.e., Hsiang Yü],
Ang went over to the side of the Han
and his territory became the Prefecture of Ho-nei.
Ch'ang had a son named Wu-tse.
Wu-tse was a Master of the Market under the Han.
Wu-tse was the father of Hsi.
Hsi was the Lord of the Fifth Rank.
All these men when they died were buried at Kao-men.
Hsi was the father og T'an,
who became The Grand Historian.
The Grand Historian studied astronomy with T'ang Tu.
He received instruction in the Book of Changes from Yang Ho.
With Master Huang he studied the theories of Tao.
The Grand Historian held office during the eras from Chien-yüan to Yüan-feng.
He was destressed that scholars seemed to fall short in their understanding and were misled by their teachers,
The Great Commentary of the Book of Changes says:
"There is one moving force, but from it a hundred thoughts and schemes arise.
All have the same objectives, though their ways are different."
The schools of Yin -yang,
the Confusianistst, the Mohists,
the Logicians, the Legalists,
and the Taoists
all strive for good government.
The difference among them is simply that they follow and teach different ways,
and some are more penetrating than others.
It has been my observation that the theories of the Yin-yang School put strong emphasis upon omens
and teach that a great many things are to be shunned and tabooed.
Hence it causes men to feel restrained and bound by fear.
But in its work of arranging correctly the all-important succession of the four seasons
it fills an essential need.
The confucians are very broad in their interests, but do not deal with much that is essential.
They labor much but achieve but slight success.
Therefore their disciplin is difficult to carry out to the fullest.
But in the way in which they order the etiquette between lord and subject and father and son,
and the proper distinctions between husband and wife and elder and younger,
they have something that cannot be altered.
Mohists are too stern in their parsimony to be followed
and therefore their teachings cannot be fully applied.
But in their emphasis upon what is basic [e.g.agricultural] and upon frugal usage
they have a point which cannot be overlooked.
The Legalists are very strict and of samll mercy.
But they have correctly defined the distinctions between lord and subject and between superior and inferior,
and these distinctions cannot be changed.
The Logicians cause men to be overnice in reasoning and often to miss the truth.
But the way in which they distinguish clearly between names and realists
is something that people cannot afford not to look into.
The Taoists teach men to live a life of spiritual concentration
and to act in harmony with the Unseen.
Their teaching is all-sufficient and embraces all things.
Its method consists
in following the seasonal order of the Yin-yang school,
selecting what is good from the Confucian and Mohists teachings,
and adopting the important points of the Logical and Legalist schools.
It modifies its positions with the times
and responds to the changes which come about in the world.
In establishing customs and practices and administering affairs,
it does nothing that is not appropriate to the time and place.
Its principle are simple and easy to practice;
it undertakes few things but achieves many sucesses.
It is not so with the Confusianists.
They consider that the ruler of men must be the model of conduct for the world.
He shall set the example, they declare, with which his ministers need only comply
he shall lead and his ministers follow.
But if it were like this, then the ruler would have to labor while the ministers followed along at their ease.
The essential of the Great Tao
is to discard strength and envy
and to do away with intelligence and understanding;
one must discard these and entrust himself to the practise of Taoism.
If the spirit of a man is too much used it will become exhausted;
if his bodily substance is put to much labor it will wear out.
If a man has early in life exhausted his spirit and body,
it is unheard of
The Yin-yang School has its teachings and ordinances which apply to each of the four seasons,
the eight trigrams,
the twelve signs of the zodiac,
and the twenty-four divisions of the year,
and it declares that anyone who follows these ordinances will meet with good fortune,
while anyone who goes against them will die or at least lose his position in life.
But this is not necessarily so.
Therefore I say
that the Yin-yang School causes men to feel restrained and bound by fear.
Spring is the time for planting, summer for nurturing,
fall for harvesting, and winter for storing away.
This is the ever-constant principle of the way of Heaven
and if one does not abide by this he cannot regulate and govern the world.
Therefore I say
that in the all-important succession of the four seasons
the Yin-yang teaching cannot be done without.
The Confucianists consider the sex Classics as their law and model.
But the books and commentaries of the Six Classics run to thousands or tens of thousands.
Generations of scholars could not master their study,
nor could a man in his whole lifetime thoroughly comprehend all their rules.
Therefore I say
that the Confucianists are broad in interests but do not deal with much that is essential,
that they labor much but achieve only slight success.
But as to the etiquette established by the Comfucianists between ruler and subject and father and son
and their distinctions between husband and wife and elder and younger,
none of the other schools can change or improve upon this.
The Mohists also honor the ways of the emperor Yao and Shun,
and speak much of their virtouous actions, saying:
"The foundations of the halls of Yao and Shun were three ch'ih high
with three steps of earth leading up;
their halls were roofed with untrimmed thatch
and their timbers and rafters were untrimmed.
These emperors ate from earthen plates
and drank from earthen bowls.
Their food was coars grain
with a soup of greens.
In summer they wore clothes of coarse fiber
and in winter the skins of deer.
The mohists bury their their dead
in coffins of t'ung wood three ts'un thick,
and when they raise their voices in mourning they do not give full vent to their grief.
They teach that funerals must be conducted in this way,
setting this up as an example for all people.
But if everyone followed their rules,
then there would be no distinction between the honorable and the lowly.
Ages differ and the times change,
and the things pople do need not always be the same.
Therefore I say
that the Mohists are too parsimonious to be followed.
But since they emphasize what is essential and are frugal in use,
theirs is the way to assure and ample supply for both individual and family.
This is the point in which the Mohists excel
and none of the other schools can afford to overlook it.
The Legalists do not distinguish between those who are close to oneself and those who are distant;
they do not differentiate between the honorable and the lowly,
but judge all men alike by their laws.
If this is so, then the obligation to treat those near to oneself with special deference and to honor those who are worthy of honor is destroyed.
Such laws can serve as an expedient for a particular time,
but they cannot be used for long.
Therefore I say
that the Legalists are strict and show little mercy.
But in so far as they place the ruler in a lofty position and the subject in a lowly on
and make clear the division of authority between the various officers of government so that there can be no usurping of unlawful power,
they have a point which the other schools cannot improve upon.
The Logicians indulge in hair splitting and toruous reasoning,
making it impossible for people to follow their meaning.
They decide everything on the basis of terms and overlook the realities.
Therefore I say
that they cause men to be overnice and often to miss the truth.
But if they can succeed in setting aside the names of things
and get at their reality so that reason is not lost,
then they have something that one cannot afford to look into.
The Daoist School propose the doctrine of "doing nothing",
but it insists that thereby "there is nothing that is not done".
Its truths are easy to practice
but its words difficult to understand.
Its teaching takes emptiness and inaction as its basis,
and compliance and accordance [with nature and the times] as its practice
It recognizes as fact that nothing is complete and finished,
that nothing is constant in form.
Therefore it is able to penetrate the spirit of all things.
It does not put material things first,
nor does it put them last;
therefore it is able to master all things.
It has laws and yet it is as though it had no laws,
for it follows the times in all its undertakings.
It has rules and yet it is as though it did not have them,
because it follows things and accords with them.
Therefore it is said
that the Sage is without great skill
but follows the changes of the times.
Emptiness is the constant law of the Tao.
Accordance is the abiding principle of the ruler.
Thus all the officers proceed to their business
with a clear understanding of their respective duties.
He who in reality comes up to what he claims to be is called upright,
but he who does not actually measure up to his name is called vain.
If a man pays no heed to vain words,
then evil will not arise.
The distinction between worthy and unworthy will become clear of itself,
and white and black will become apparent.
Thus one can choose the one and discard the other
and thereby accomplish all things.
He can be at one with the Great Tao
which, formless and dark,
yet lightens the whole world.
Thus may one return again to the Nameless.
It is the spirit which gives life to all men
and they assume their form in bodily substance.
If the spirit be put to great use it will become exhausted.
If the body be made to labor greatly it will become worn out.
When substance and spirit part there is death.
He who is dead cannot return to life,
for that which has become separated cannot again be joined.
Therefore the Sage regards those things with gravity.
From this we may see
that the spirit is the basis of life
and the substance is its vessel.
If a man does not first put at rest his spirit and substance,
but says instead,
"I can govern the world!",
what reason can there be for his words?
Since The Grand Historian was always in charge of astronomical affairs
he was not concerned with the governing of the people.
He had a son named Ch'in.
Ch'ien was born at Lung-men.
He plowed and pastured on the sunny side of the hills along the River.
At the age of ten he could read the old writings.
When he was twenty he traveled south to the Yangtse and Hui rivers [Kiangsu],
he climbed Hui-chi
and looked for the Cave of Yü [Chekiang],

He sailed down the Yüan

He observed the customs and practices inherited from Confucius

in Tsou. He met with trouble and danger in P'o

Then he passed through Liang

After this Ch'ien intered government service as a Lang-chung.
He took part in the western expedition to the south of Pa and Shu,
marching south

Tse, and K'un-ming.
He returned and reported on his mission.
In the same year [110 B.C.] the Son of Heaven first performed the Feng Sacrifice for the house of Han.
But the Grand Historian [Ssu-ma T'an] was forced to stay behind at Chu-nan
and could not take part in the ceremony.
He was filled with resentment over this and lay on the point of death.
When his son Ch'en returned from his mission,
he visited his father at the place where he was staying between the Lo and Yellow rivers.
The Grand Historian grasped his hand and said, weeping,
"Our ancestors were Grand Historans for the house of Chou.
From the most ancient times they were eminent and renowned when in the days of Yü and Hsia
they were in charge of astronomical affairs.
In later ages our family declined.
Will this tradition end with me?
If you in turn become Grand Historian,
you must continue the work of our ancestors.
Now the Son of Heaven, following the tradition of a thousand years,
will perform the Feng Sacrifice on Mount Tai.
But I shall not be able to be present.
Such is my fate!
Such indeed is my fate
After I die,
you will become Grand Historian.
When you become Grand Historian,
you must not forget what I have desired to expound and write.
Now filial piety begins with the serving of your parents;
next you must serve your sovereign;
and finally you must make something of yourself,
that your name may go down through the ages
for the glory of your father and mother.
This is the most important part of filial piety.
Everyone praise the Duke of Chou,
saying that he was able to set forth in word and song the virtues of King Wen and King Wu,
publishing abroad the Odes of Chou and Shao;
he set forth the thoughts and ideals of T'ai-wang and Wang Chi,
extending his words back to Kung Liu,
and paying honour to Hou Chi.
After the reigns of Yu and Li
the way of the ancient kings fell into disuse,
and rites and music declined.
Confucius revived the old ways and restored what had been abandoned,
expounding the Odes and Documents
and making the Spring and Autumn Annals.
From that time until today men of learning have taken these as their models.
It has now been over four hundred years since the capture of the unicorn.
The various feudal states have merged together
and the old records and chronicles have become scattered and lost.
Now the house of Han has arisen
and all the world is united under one rule.
I have been Grand Historian, and yet I have failed to set forth a record of all the enlightened rulers and wise lords, the faithful ministers and gentlemen who were ready to die for duty.
I am fearful that the historical materials will be neclected and lost.
You must remember and think of this.
Ch'ien bowed his head and wept, saying,
"I, your son, am ignorant and unworthy,
but I shall endeaver to set forth in full the reports of antiquity which have come from our ancestors.
I shall not dare to be remiss!"
Three years afte the death of his father, Ch'ien became Grand Historian.
He read the various historical records and the books of the stone and metal caskets.
Five years after this was the first year of the era T'ai-ch'u.
At dawn on the first day of the eleventh month, the day chia-tzu [Dec. 25,105], the zenith of winter,
the calendar of the heavens was first corrected
and set up in the Illustrious Hall.
All spirits received the chronology.
The Grand Historian remarks:
"My father used to say to me,
'Five hundred years after the Duke of Chou died Confucius appeared.
It has now been five hundred years since the death of Confucius.
There must be someone who can succeed to the enlightened ages of the past,
who can set right to transmission of the Book of Changes,
continue the Spring and Autumn Annals,
and search into the world of the Odes and Documents, the rites and music.'
Was this not his ambition?
How can I, his son, dare to neglect his will."
The high Minister Hu Sui once asked,
"For what reason was it that Confucius in ancient times made the Spring and Autumn Annals?'
The Grand Historian replied,
"I have heard Master Tung say,
'When Confucius was Chief Minister of Justice in Lu,
the ways of the Chou had declined and fallen into disuse.
The feudal lords abused him
and the high officials obstructed his plans.
Confucius realized that his words were not being heeded,
nor his doctrines put into practice.
So he made a critical judgement of the rights and wrongs of a period of two hundred and forty-two years
in order to provide a standard of rules and ceremonies for the world.
He criticized the emperors,
reprimanded the feudal lords,
and condemned the high officials
in order to make known the business of a true ruler and that was all.
Confucius said,
"If I wish to set forth my theoretical judments,
nothing is as good as illustrating them through the depth and clarity of actual events."
"Above, the Spring and Autumn Kings,
makes clear the Way of the Three Kings,
and below it discusses the regulation of human affairs.
It disguishes what is supicious and doubtful,
clarifies right and wrong
and settles points which are uncertain.
It calls good good and bad bad,
honors the worthy, and condemns the unworthy.
It preserves states which are lost
and restores the perishing family.
It brings to light what was neglected and restores what was abandoned.
The Book of Changes makes clear haven and earth, the yin and the yang, the four seasons and the five elements.
Therefore it is most useful in matters of change.
The rites regulates human relations,
and so is excellent in matters of conduct.
The Book of Documents records the deeds of the former kings,
and so is most useful in government.
The Odes tells of monuments and rivers, ravines and valleys, of birds and beasts, plants and trees, and the male and female of beasts and birds.
Thus is best expressed the sentiments of the people.
Through music joy is achieved,
and so it excels in harmony and peace.
The Spring and Autumn differentiates between right and wrong,
and so is most helpful in ruling men.
Thus the Rites regulates mankind,
music spread harmony,
the Documents tells us of deeds,
the Odes expresses the will of men,
the Changes relates of transformation,
and the Spring and Autumn discusses right.
"Therefore, for dispersing revolt and turning the people back to the right,
none of the other Classics can compare to the Spring and Autumn.

the Lord of Hsü had already died.
At this point, Chi Cha then took off his precious sword,
hung it on the tree at the grave of the Lord of Hsü, and left.
His attendants said,
"The Lord of Hsü has already died.
To whom are you still giving [the sword]?"
Chi Tzu said,
"This is not the case.
I had already promised it to him in my heart from the beginning.
How can I betray my heart because of his death?"
In the seventh year (541 B.C.),
Noble Scion Wei of Ch'u murdered his king, Chia Ao (r. 544–541 B.C.), and was enthroned
as King Ling (r. 540–529 B.C.).
In the tenth year (538 B.C.),
King Ling of Ch'u assembled the feudal lords and led them on a punitive expedition to Chu-fang in Wu,
in order to execute Ch'ing Feng of Ch'i.
Wu also attacked Ch'u,
took three towns, and left.
In the eleventh year (537 B.C.),
Ch'u again came and launched a punitive expedition against Wu
reaching Yu-lou.
In the twelfth year (536 B.C.),
Ch'u again came and launched a punitive expedition [against Wu],
stationing [its troops] at Kan-hsi.
The troops of Ch'u were routed.
In the seventeenth year (531 B.C.),
Yü-chai, the King, expired
and his younger brother Yü-mo (r. 530–527 B.C.) was enthroned.
In the second year (529 B.C.) of Yü-mo, the King,
Ch'i-chi, a noble scion of Ch'u, murdered his lord, King Ling, and enthroned himself in his place.
In the fourth year (527 B.C.),
Yü-mo, the King, expired,
intending to transfer the throne to his younger brother Chi Cha.
Chi Cha yielded
and fled.
At this point, a person in Wu said,
"The former king had a mandate:
'When the elder brother expired, the younger brother should be enthroned in his place
so that the throne would be sure to reach Chi Tzu.
Now that Chi Tzu has fled from the throne,
Yü-mo, the King, was the successor to the throne.
Now that he has expired,
his son should replace him.'"
Thus they enthroned Liao (r. 526–515 B.C.) the son of Yü-mo, the King, as king.
In the second year of King Liao (525 B.C.),
Noble Scion Kuang led a punitive expedition against Ch'u,
was defeated, and lost the royal ship.
Kuang was afraid.
He assaulted Ch'u
and regained the royal ship.
In the fifth year (522 B.C.),
a fugitive subject of Ch'u, Wu Tzu Hsü, fled [Ch'u] and came to Wu.
Noble Scion Kuang received him as a guest.
Noble Scion Kuang
was the son of Chu-fan, the King.
He always considered that: "Among the four brothers of my father's generation,
the throne should have been passed to Chi Tzu.
Since Chi Tzu did not accept the state,
Kuang's [i.e., my] father was first set up.
Since the throne did not pass to Chi Tzu,
Kuang [i.e., I] should be enthroned."
He surreptitiously took in worthy knights,
intending to make a surprise attack on Liao, the King.
In the eight year (519 B.C.),
Wu sent Noble Scion Kuang to lead a punitive expedition against Ch'u.
He defeated the Ch'u troops,
[then] went to Chü-chao to welcome the mother of Chian, the former Heir of Ch'u, and returned with her.
Taking advantage of an expedition to the north,
he defeated the troops of Ch'en
and Ts'ai.
In the ninth year (518 B.C.),
Noble Scion Kuang led an expedition against Ch'u
and seized Chü-ch'ao
and Chung-li.
Earlier, a maiden from the Pei-liang Clan of a Ch'u border-town had fought with a girl from a Wu border-town over [mulberry leaves].
Their [sic!] families of the two girls became angry and destroyed each other.
When the county heads of the border-towns of both states head of this,
they became angry and attacked each other;
the Wu border-town was destroyed.
The King of Wu was angry.
For this reason, he sent an expedition against Ch'u,
took two cities, and left.
When Wu Tzu Hsü first fled to Wu,
he advised the King of Wu of the benefits of launching a punitive attack against Ch'u.
Noble Scion Kuang said,
"Both Hsü's father and elder brother were killed in the state of Ch'u
and he wants to avenge himself.
I have not yet seen any benefit."
From this Wu Yen [i.e., Wu Tzu Hsü] knew that Kuang had ulterior motives.
He thus sought out a brave man, Chuan Chu,
and had him see Kuang.
Kuang was pleased
and thus treated Wu Tzu Hsü as an honorable guest.
Tzu Hsü retired [from court] and plowed in the wilds
in order to await Chuan Chu's affair.
In the winter of the twelfth year (515 B.C.),
King P'ing of Ch'u expired.
In the spring of the thirteenth year (514 B.C.),
the [King of] Wu intended to take advantage of the Ch'u's period of mourning to launch an expedition against Ch'u.
He sent Noble Scion Kai-yü and
Chu-yung to lead troops to besiege Lu and
Ch'ien in Ch'u and sent Chi Cha to the Chin
to observe developments among the feudal lords.
Ch'u dispatched troops cutting off the retreat of the Wu troops.
The Wu troops were not able to return.
At this, Noble Scion Kuang of Wu said:
"This is an opportune time that we can not lose."
He said to Chuan Chu,
"If we do not demand, what shall we gain?
I am the true successor to the King and
should be enthroned.
I intend to seek that.
Even if Chi Tzu comes back,
he will not depose me."
Chuan Chu said:
"Liao, the King, can be killed.
His mother is old and his son is young.
The two noble scions have led their troops to attack Ch'u and
had their retreat cut off by Ch'u.
Just now Wu is menaced by Ch'u from without,
and is emptied [of troops] and devoid of outspoken vassals within.
This indicated they can do nothing to us!"
Kuang said,
"My life
[depends] on your life."
On the ping-tzu of the fourth month (28 February 514 B.C.),
Kuang hid some knights in armor in an underground room
and invited Liao, the King, to have a drink.
Liao, the King, let his troops line up on the road
from the King's Palace to Kuang's house.
Liao, the King's kinsmen were at the gates and doors, on the steps and mats,
holding long rapiers.
Noble Scion Kuang pretended to have a pain in his foot
and entered the underground room.
He let Chuan Chu put a dagger into a broiled fish to present [to the king].
As [Chuan Chu] grasped the dagger to stab Liao, the King,
long rapiers crisscrossed his chest,
[but] finally he murdered Liao, the King.
Noble Scion Kuang eventually enthroned himself as king in his place.
This was Ho-lü, the King of Wu (r. 514–496 B.C.).
Ho-lü then appointed Chuan Chu's son an excellency.
When Chi Tzu arrived,
he said,
"If he does not abolish sacrifices to the former lords,
does not abolish a master for the common people,
and the gods of soil and grain receive their sacrifices,
then he is my lord.
Whom do I dare to resent?
I shall mourn the dead [king] and serve the living [king]
so as to await Heaven's mandate.
It was not I who gave rise to the chaos.
I shall follow whomever has been enthroned.
It is the way of our ancestors."
Reporting on his mission [to Liao, the King,],
he wept at Liao's grave.
He returned to his position to await [orders].
When the two noble scions of Wu, Chu-yung and
Kai-yü, having led troops and been surrounded by Ch'u [troops],
hear that Noble Scion Kuang had murdered Liao, the King, and had enthroned himself,
they led their troops to surrender to Ch'u.
[The King of] Ch'u enfeoffed them at Shu.
In the first year of King Ho-lü (514 B.C.),
[Ho-lü] raised Wu Tzu Hsü to be the Officer of Foreign Affairs and deliberated state affairs with him.
[The King of] Ch'u executed Po Chou-li.
His grandson, Po P'i, ran away and fled to Wu.
[The King of] Wu made him a Grand Master.
In the third year (512 B.C.),
Ho-lü, the King of Wu, together with [Wu] Tzu Hsü and
P'o [sic!] P'i, led troops to attack Ch'u,
seized Shu,
and killed the two noble scions who were fugitive commanders from Wu.
Kuang made plans intending to enter Ying.
The general Sun Wu said:
"The people are weary.
[We] cannot [enter Ying] now.
[Let us] wait."
In the fourth year (511 B.C.),
[Wu] launched a punitive expedition against Ch'u
and took Lu and Ch'ien.
In the fifth year (510 B.C.),
[Wu] launched a punitive expedition against Yüeh
and defeated it.
In the sixth year (509 B.C.),
Ch'u sent Tzu-ch'ang Nang Wa to launch a punitive expedition against Wu.
[The Wu troops] met and assaulted them,
crushing the Ch'u army at Yü-chang,
taking Chü-ch'ao of Ch'u, and returning.
In the ninth year (506 B.C.),
Ho-lü, the King of Wu, asked Wu Tzu Hsü and
Sun Wu:
"At the start you said that we could not enter Ying.
How about now?"
The two masters replied:
"The Ch'u commander Tzu-ch'ang is greedy.
T'ang and
Ts'ai both harbor resentment against him.
If Your Majesty definitely intends to launch a large-scale punitive expedition against Ch'u,
it will be possible only when you have obtained [the support of] T'and and Ts'ai."
Ho-lü followed this [advice].
He raised all his troops and,
together with T'ang
and Ts'ai, moved west to launch an expedition against Ch'u,
reaching as far as the Han River.
Ch'u also dispatched troops to resist Wu
each [army] drawing into [battle] array on one side of the river.
Fu-kai, the younger brother of Ho-lü, the King of Wu, intended to give battle.
Ho-lü did not consent to this.
Fu-kai said:
"Your Majesty already entrusted His Vassal with the troops.
In managing troops, favorable conditions are paramount.
What else are we waiting for?"
Then he led his troops of five thousand soldiers to make a surprise attack on Ch'u.
The Ch'u troops were crushed and
ran off. At this, the King of Wu loosed his troops to pursue them.
When they arrived at Ying,
they fought five battles.
The Ch'u troops were defeated five times.
King Chao of Ch'u escaped from Ying and
fled to Yün.
The younger brother of the Magistrate of Yün intended to murder King Chao.
King Chao and the Magistrate of Yün fled to Sui.
And then the Wu troops entered Ying.
Tzu Hsü and
Po P'i lashed the corpse of King P'ing to avenge their fathers.
In the spring of the tenth year (505 B.C.),
Yüeh heard that the King of Wu was at Ying
and the state [of Wu] was weakly defended,
he thus launched an expedition against Wu.
Wu sent a separate force to attack Yüeh.
Ch'u informed Ch'in of its straits.
Ch'in sent troops to rescue Ch'u and attack Wu.
The Wu troops were defeated.
Fu-kai, Ho-lü's younger brother, saw that the Wu troops were defeated by Ch'in and Yüeh respectively,
and the King of Wu stayed in Ch'u and could not leave.
Fu-kai fled and returned to Wu, investing himself as the King of Wu.
When Ho-lü heard of it,
he thus led his troops to return
and attacked Fu-kai.
Fu-kai was defeated and escaped to Ch'u.
Thus King Chao of Ch'u was able to re-enter Ying in the ninth month,
and enfeoffed Fu-kai at T'ang-ch'i,
making him [a member of] the T'ang-ch'i Clan.
In the eleventh year (504 B.C.),
the King of Wu sent the Heir, Fu-ch'ai, to launch an expedition against Ch'u;
he took P'an.
[The King of] Ch'u was afraid and left Ying, moving [the capital] to Jo.
In the fifteenth year (500 B.C.),
Confucius assisted [in the government of] Lu.
In the summer of the nineteenth year (496 B.C.),
Wu launched an expedition against Yüeh.
Kou-chien, the King of Yüeh (r. 497–465 B.C.), met them struck them at Tsui-li.
Yüeh sent some warriors willing to die to challenge them to battle.
In three ranks they approached the Wu troops,
cried out, and cut their own throats.
While the Wu soldiers were watching this,
Yüeh took advantage to attack the Wu troops
and defeated them at Ku-su [Tower].
They injured Ho-lü, the King of Wu's finger
and caused the Wu troops to withdraw seven li.
The King of Wu took ill from the wound and died.
Ho-lü had ordered the enthronement of Fu-ch'ai, the Heir,
and had said to him,
"Can you forget that Kou-chien killed your father?"
[Fu-ch'ai] repiled,
"I dare not!"
Three years later,
he thus retaliated against Yüeh.
In the first year of Fu-ch'ai (495 B.C.), the King (r. 495–473 B.C.),
he made Grand Master Po P'i the Grand Stewart.
He practiced fighting and shooting
and always kept retaliating against Yüeh as his goal.
In the second year (494 B.C.),
The King of Wu with all his crack troops attacked Yüeh
and defeated them at Fu-chiao
in retaliation for Ku-su.
Kou-chien, the King of Yüeh then had five thousand armored soldiers garrison K'uai-chi.
He sent Grand Master Chung to seek peace through Grand Steward P'i,
requesting to relinquish his state and make his people vassals and concubines [of the King of Wu].
When the King of Wu was about to consent to this,
Wu Tzu Hsü admonished him, saying,
"Long ago, the Kuos killed [the Lord of] Chen-kuan in order to attack Chen-hsün,
and then destroyed the Hsia emperor, Hsiang.
Emperor Hsiang's concubine, Hou-min, had just become pregnant.
She fled to the Jeng and gave birth to Shao-k'ang.
Shao-k'ang became the Chief Shepherd of the Jeng.
The Kuo further intended to kill Shao-k'ang.
Shao-k'ang fled to the Yü.
The Yü recalled Hsia's virtue.
Thereupon, they married Shao-k'ang to two of their women and enfeoffed him at Kuan,
in possession of fields of one ch'eng
and a populace of one lu.
Later, Shao-k'ang finally gathered the populace of Hsia
and reestablished their [the Hsia] official positions.
He sent someone to entrap the Kuo,
consequently destroying them.
He recovered the achievements of Yü,
sacrificed to Hsia and concurrently to Heaven,
and did not neglect 'old things.'
Today, Wu is not as mighty as the Kuo,
but Kou-chien is even greater than Shao-k'ang.
If we do not now take advantage of this and destroy him,
[but] instead intend to be lenient to him,
Will that not be disastrous?
Moreover, Kou-chien by nature can endure hardship.
If we do not destroy him now,
later we shall surely regret it."
The King of Wu did not listen to him.
He listened to Grand Steward P'i.
He finally consented to peace with Yüeh,
made a covenant with them, and dismissed his troops, and left.
In the seventh year (489 B.C.),
Fu-ch'ai, the King of Wu, heard that Duke Ching of Ch'i (r. 547–490 B.C.) had died, the great ministers [of Ch'i] were contending for favor,
and the new lord was young.
Tzu Hsü admonished saying,
Thus he raised troops and went north to launch a punitive expedition against Ch'i.
Kou-chien, the King of Yüeh, neither has two courses when eating
nor two colors in his dress.
He laments the dead and inquires after the sick.
Moreover, he intends [to find] the means by which to put his populace to use.
As long as this person lives,
he will certainly bring dismay to Wu.
Right now Yüeh is a malady [in Wu's] viscera and heart and Your Majesty does not give it precedence,
but concentrates on Ch'i–
is this not indeed an error?"
The King of Wu did not listen to him.
He launched a punitive expedition against Ch'i,
and defeated the Ch'i troops at Ai-ling.
When he reached Tseng,
he summoned Duke Ai of Lu (r. 494–468 B.C.) demanding [from Lu] a hundred sets of sacrificial animals.
Viscount K'ang of Chi sent Tzu-kung to use the Chou ritual to dissuade Grand Stewart P'i
and thus was able to put a stop to [the King of Wu's demand].
[The King of Wu] took advantage of this to stay and overrun territory in the southern parts of Ch'i and Lu.
In the ninth year (487 B.C.),
[the King of Wu] launched a punitive expedition against Lu on behalf of the state of Tsou.
When he reached Lu, he made a covenant with Lu and left.
In the tenth year (486 B.C.),
he took advantage of this [the covenant with Lu] to launch an expedition against Ch'i and returned.
In the eleventh year,
he again led an expedition north against Ch'i.
Kou-chien, King of Yüeh, led his people to pay homage to [the King of] Wu,
presenting generous tribute to him.
[The King of] Wu was pleased.
Only Tzu Hsü was apprehensive,
and said,
"This means [the King of Wu] will abandon Wu."
He remonstrated with him by saying,
"Yüeh is situated at [our] viscera and hear.
Now you have obtained your goals in Ch'i,
[but] it is as if [you had won] a field of stones
which is of no use.
Moreover, the 'P'an-keng chin kao' (The Announcement of P'an-keng) has [the line] 'Those who have fallen, don't leave them alive!'
This is the way that Shang rose up."
The King of Wu did not listen
and sent Tzu Hsü to Ch'i.
Tzu Hsü entrusted his son to the Pao Clan [in the State of Ch'i],
then returned and reported to the King of Wu.
When the King of Wu head this [that Tzu Hsü had committed his son to the Pao Clan],
he was enraged
and bestowed on Tzu Hsü the sword of Chu-lü for him to die with.
When he was about to die,
he said:
"Plant my grave with catalpas
to allow them to be made into an instrument [i.e., a coffin].
Gouge out my eyes and hang them on the east gate [of the capital] of Wu
so that I may observe Yüeh destroy Wu."
The Pao Clan of Ch'i murdered Duke Tao of Ch'i (r. 488–485 B.C.).
When the King of Wu heard this,
he wept for three days outside the gate of his military camp.
He attacked Ch'i by sea.
The men of Ch'i defeated Wu.
The King of Wu then led his troops to return.
In the thirteenth year (483 B.C.),
[the King of] Wu summoned the lords of Lu and
Wey to him at T'o-kao.
In the spring of the fourteenth year (482 B.C.),
the King of Wu went north to meet with the feudal lords at Huang-ch'ih.
He intended to make himself Hegemony of the Central States so as to preserve the Chou [royal] household.
On the ping-tzu day of the sixth month (11 May 482 B.C.),
Kou-chien, King of Yüeh launched a punitive expedition against Wu.
On the yi-yu day (20 May),
five thousand men of Yüeh battled with Wu.
On the ping-hsü day (21 May)
they captured Yu, the Heir of Wu.
On the ting-hai day (22 May)
they entered [the capital of] Wu.
The people of Wu reported the defeat to King Fu-ch'ai.
Fu-ch'ai hated that this would be heard [by others].
Someone disclosed his words.
The King of Wu was angry
and beheaded seven people in his tent.
On the hsing-ch'ou day of the seventh month (5 June),
the Kind of Wu contended with Duke Ting of Chin (r. 511–475 B.C.) for preeminence.
The King of Wu said:
"With regard to the Chou House, I am of the eldest."
Duke Ting of Chin said:
"With regard to those of the cognomen Chi, I am of the eldest."
Chao Yang became angry
and was about to launch a punitive expedition against Wu.
Then they gave preeminence to Duke Ting of Chun.
The King of Wu having made the covenant,
bid farewell to [the Duke of] Chin,
intending to attack Sung.
Grand Steward P'i said:
"You may be victorious, but you cannot linger there."
He then led the troops to return to his state.
The state having lost the Heir,
the capital was emptied [of troops].
As the king had been out of the state for a long time,
his soldiers were all exhausted and worn out.
At this, [the King of Wu] sent lavish gifts in order to seek peace with Yüeh.
In the fifteenth year (481 B.C.),
T'ien Ch'ang of Ch'i murdered Duke Chien.
In the eighteenth year (478 B.C.),
Yüeh became increasingly powerful.
Kou-chien, the King of Yüeh, led his troops again to launch a punitive expedition and defeated the Wu army at Li-tse.
Ch'u destroyed Ch'en.
In the twentieth year (476 B.C.),
Kou-chien, the King of Yüeh, launched an expedition against Wu.
In the twenty-first year (475 B.C.),
he then besieged the capital of Wu.
On the ting-mao day of the eleventh month of the twenty-third year (5 November 473 B.C.),
Yüeh defeated Wu.
Kou-chien, the King of Yüeh, intended to move Fu-ch'ai, the King of Wu, to Yung-tong,
conferring upon him a fief of one hundred families.
The King of Wu said,
"I am old now
and cannot serve Your Lord and Majesty any more.
I regret not employing the words of Tzu Hsü,
causing myself to fall into this [position]."
He then cut his own throat and died.
The King of Yüeh destroyed Wu
and executed Grand Steward P'i,
considering him to have been disloyal,
and returned.
His Honor the Grand Scribe says:
"Confucius said:
'T'ai-po could be said to have been extremely virtuous.
Three times he yielded the world.
[But] people were unable to learn anything [about this] and praise him'
After I read the ancient text of the Spring and Autumn [Annals],
I understood that [the state of] Yü of the central states and [the state] of Kou-wu in the Ching-man [regions] were elder and younger brother [states].
Yen-ling Chi Tzu [Chi Cha] was humane in his heart.
He longed for righteousness without end,
he perceived subtleties and scorned the pure from the impure.
Alas,
what a lord of vast vision and broad knowledge was he!
T'ai-kung of Ch'i, Hereditary House 2
Lü Shang, T'ai-kung Wang (Our Grandfather's Expectation),
was a native of the coast of the East Sea.
His ancestors were once Chiefs of the Four Sacred Mountains,
who in assisting Yü in regulating the water and the land, won great merit.
In the time of Yeu [sic!] and Hsia, they were enfeoffed with Lü,
some were enfeoffed with Shen,
and had the cognomen Chiang-shih.
In the time of the Hsia and the Shang,
some [descendants] were enfeoffed with Shen and Lü as collateral branches of descendants,
and some become commoners.
[Lü] Shang was one of their later remote descendants.
Originally their cognomen was Chiang.
Since they took their cognomen from their fief,
he was called Lü Shang.
Lü Shang supposedly destitute and in dire straits,
as he had grown old,
angled for fish so as to seek out the Lord of the West of Chou.
When the Lord of the West was about to go out hunting,
he divined by shells and bones about it,
and the oracle read: "What you will capture will be neither a horned dragon nor an unhorned dragon,
neither a tiger nor a brown bear.
What you will capture will be the assistant of the Hegemony to the King."
At this, the lord of the West of Chou went hunting,
and he indeed encountered T'ai-kung on the north bank of the Wei.
He spoke with him, was greatly pleased
and said,
"Our grandfather, the late ruler, once said,
'There will be a sage coming to Chou,
and Chou will arise by means of him.'
Are you truly that man?
Our grandfather has expected you a long time."
For this reason, he called him
T'ai-kung Wang (Our Grandfather's Expectation).
He took him back together in his own chariot
and established him as [Grand] Tutor.
Some say
T'ai-kung's knowledge was broad
and that he had once served Chow.
Chow neglected the Way,
so he [T'ai-kung Wang] left him.
He travelled around advising the feudal lords,
met no success,
and finally went west to turn to the Lord of the West of Chou.
Still others say
Lü Shang was an untried scholar
who had gone into reclusion at the seacoast.
When the Lord of the West of Chou was detained in Yu-li,
San Yi-sheng and
Hung Yao, who had known about [Lü shang] for a long time, recruited him.
Lü shang also said,
"I have heard that the Lord of the West is worthy
and further that he is good at caring for the elderly.
Why not go to him?"
On behalf of the Lord of the West, these three men sought out beautiful women and rare objects,
and offered these to Chow
so as to ransom the Lord of the West.
The Lord of the West was able to get out
and return to his state.
The tales about how Lü Shang came to serve the Chou are different,
but their essence is he is always the Tutor of Kings Wen (r. ca. 1099/56–1050 B.C.) and Wu (r. ca. 1049–1043 B.C.).
After Ch'ang, Lord of the West of Chou, was released from Yu-li and returned home,
he secretly plotted with Lü Shang and cultivated his virtue so as to overthrow the Shang government.
These affairs involved many military tactics and marvelous plans.
For this reason, when people in later generations spoke of the military and touched on Chou's secret tactics, they always trace [things] back to T'ai-kung's making his basic plans.
The Lord of the West of Chou governed fairly.
After he judged a dispute between the Yü and Jui peoples,
poets praised the Lord of the West for receiving the mandate, calling him King Wen.
He chastised [the Marquis of] Ch'ung,
the Mi-hsü,
the Ch'üan-Yi (The Dog Yi),
and built the city of Feng on a grand scale.
Of three parts of the world,
two of these had turned to the Chou;
and T'ai-kung's plotting and planning had a great part.
King Wen passed away
and King Wu ascended the throne.
In the ninth year [of King Wu's reign],
[King] Wu intended to cultivate King Wen's enterprise.
He went east leading an expedition to observe whether the feudal lords would gather together or not.
When the troops set out,
Shih Shang Fu (Tutor Uncle Shang) held a yellow halberd in his left hand
and in his right hand grasped a white oxtail banner so as to swear an oath:
"Grey rhinoceros! Grey rhinoceros!
Assemble all your people
and your boats and oars.
Those who come late will be beheaded!"
Then they arrived at Meng-chin,
and the feudal lords who met there without any prearrangement numbered eight hundred.
The feudal lords all said,
"Chow can be chastised!"
King Wu said,
"He cannot be yet."
After returning the troops,
he composed the "T'ai-shih" (The Great Oath) with T'ai-kung.
After two years,
Chow killed Prince Pi-kan
and imprisoned the Viscount of Chi.
King Wu was going to chastise Chow.
When he divined by tortoise-shell,
the sign was inauspicious
and a storm suddenly broke.
The various dukes were all frightened,
and only T'ai-kung vigorously urged King Wu.
At this, King Wu finally set out.
On the chia-tzu day of the first month of the eleventh year [of King Wu's reign],
he swore an oath at Mu-yeh
to chastise Chow of the Shang.
Chow's troops were routed,
and Chow turned and fled.
He climbed Lu-t'ai (Deer Terrace).
[King Wu] then pursued and beheaded Chow.
The next day
King Wu stood at the earth-god altar.
The various dukes offered up pure water,
Feng, Wei K'ang Shu (Feng, Prince of K'ang of and [sic!] Wei) spread the colorful straw mats,
Shih Shang Fu led the sacrificial animal,
and Scribe Yi made an invocation on bamboo slips
so as to inform the spirits about the punishment of Chow's offenses.
They distributed the money from Lu-t'ai,
and issued grain from the Chü-ch'iao (Great Bridge [Granary])
to relieve the poor people.
They raised a tumulus over Pi-kan's grave,
released the Viscount of Chi from prison,
and moved the Nine Tripods [to Chou],
perfecting the administration of the Chou,
and starting the world anew.
Shih Shang Fu's plotting had a great part.
At this time, having pacified the Shang and ruling the world as a king,
King Wu enfeoffed Shih Shang Fu with Ying-ch'iu in Ch'i.
When [Shih Shang Fu] was heading east to his state,
he lodged along the way, traveling slowly.
The innkeeper said,
"I have heard that an opportune moment is difficult to gain and easy to lose.
The guest sleeps so contentedly.
Perhaps he will not be the one who is going to his state."
On hearing this, T'ai-kung
got dressed in the night and set out,
arriving at his state in the predawn light.
The Marquis of Lai came to campaign,
contending with T'ai-kung for Ying-ch'iu.
Ying-ch'iu bordered on Lai.
The Lai people
were Yi.
They had encountered the chaos of Chow, and the Chou had only just stabilized [the world]
and had not yet been able to settle distant regions.
This is why they contended with T'ai-kung for the state.
When T'ai-kung arrived at his state,
he cultivated administration,
adapted their social customs,
simplified their social codes,
opened up the enterprises of commerce and crafts,
facilitated the profits from fish and salt;
and people in great numbers went over to Ch'i,
and Ch'i became a great state.
When King Ch'eng of Chou (r. ca. 1067–1031 B.C.) was young,
Kuan [Shu Hsien] (Hsien, Prince of Kuan) and Ts'ai [Shu Tu] (Tu, Prince of Ts'ai) made rebellion,
and the Huai-Yi rebelled against the Chou.
Then [King Ch'eng] sent Duke K'ang of Chao to order T'ai-kung:
"East to the sea,
west to the Ho,
south to Mu-ling,
and north to Wu-ti;
as for the Five Feudal Lords and the Nine Chiefs,
you have in reality gained the power to chastise them."
Because of this, Ch'i gained the power to undertake punitive campaigns and expeditions,
becoming a great state
with its capital at Ying-ch'iu.
Supposedly when T'ai-kung expired he was over one hundred years old.
His son, Lü Chi, Duke Ting, was invested.
When Duke Ting expired,
his son, Te, Duke Yi, was invested.
When Duke Yi expired,
his son, Tz'u-mu, Duke Kuei, was invested.
When Duke Kuei expired,
his son, Pu-ch'en, Duke Ai, was invested.
At the time of Duke Ai,
the Marquis of Chi slandered him to the Chou.
The Chou boiled Duke Ai alive and invested his younger brother, Ching.
This was Duke Hu (r. ?–860 B.C.).
Duke Hu moved the capital to Po-ku,
and this was at the time of King Yi of Chou (r. ca. 865–858 B.C.).
Duke Ai's younger brother by the same mother, Shan, harbored resentment towards Duke Hu.
The, together with his faction, he led the men of Ying-ch'iu in a surprise attack, killed Duke Hu and invested himself.
He was Duke Hsien (r. 859–851 B.C.).
In the first year of Duke Hsien (859 B.C.),
he expelled all the sons of Duke Hu,
and took the opportunity to move the Po-ku capital
and set up his administration at Lin-tzu.
In the ninth year (851 B.C.),
Duke Hsien expired,
and his son, Shou, Duke Wu, (r. 850–825 B.C.), was invested.
In the ninth year of Duke Wu (842 B.C.),
King Li of Chou (r. ca. 857–828 B.C.) came out [of the Chou capital] and fled
to reside at Chih.
In the tenth year (841 B.C.),
the royal house was in chaos
and great vassals took charge of the government.
This [era] was designated
In the twenty-fourth year (827 B.C.),
King Hsüan of Chou (r. 827–782 B.C.) was first invested.
In the twenty-sixth year (825 B.C.),
Duke Wu expired.
His son, Wu-chi, Duke Li (r. 824–816 B.C.), was invested.
Duke Li was tyrannical.
For this reason, when a son of Duke Hu reentered Ch'i,
some people of Ch'i intended to invest him.
Together they then attacked and killed Duke Li.
Duke Hu's son also died in battle.
The people of Ch'i thereupon invested Duke Li's son, Chi's, as the lord.
This was Duke Wen (r. 815–804 B.C.),
who, however, executed the seventy people who had killed Duke Li.
In the twelfth year of Duke Wen (804 B.C.), he expired.
His son, T'o, Duke Ch'eng (r. 803–795 B.C.), was invested.
In the ninth year of Duke Ch'eng (795 B.C.), he expired.
His son, Kou, Duke Chuang (r. 794–731 B.C.), was invested.
In the twenty-fourth year of Duke Chuang (771 B.C.),
the Ch'üan-Jung (Dog Jung) killed King Yu (r. 781–771 B.C.),
and the Chou went east to move to Lo.
Ch'in was ranked as a feudal lord for the first time.
In the fifty sixth year (739 B.C.),
Chin cut down their lord, Marquis Chao (r. 745–739 B.C.).
In the sixty-fourth year (731 B.C.),
Duke Chuang expired.
His son, Lu-fu, Duke Hsi (r. 730–698 B.C.) was invested.
In the ninth year of Duke Hsi (722 B.C.),
Duke Yin of Lu (r. 722–712 B.C.) was first invested.
In the nineteenth year (712 B.C.),
Duke Hua of Lu (r. 711–694 B.C.) cut down his elder brother, Duke Yin, and invested himself as lord.
In the twenty-fifth year (706 B.C.),
the Pei-Jung (Northern Jung) attacked Ch'i.
Cheng sent the Heir, Hu, to come to the aid of Ch'i.
Ch'i wanted to marry his daughter to him.
Hu said,
"Cheng is small; Ch'i is large.
[She] is not my match."
Consequently, he refused him.
In the thirty-second year (699),
Duke Hsi's younger brother, Yi Chung Nien, who had the same mother, died.
His son was called Kung-sun Wu-chih (729–685 B.C.).
Duke Hsi loved him
and ordered that he be provided official rank, salary and garments on a part with [those of] the Heir.
In the thirty-third year (698),
Duke Hsi expired
and Heir Chu-erh was invested.
He was Duke Hsiang (r. 697–686 B.C.).
It was the first year of Duke Hsiang (697 B.C.).
When he had been the Heir,
Duke Hsiang had once fought with Wu-chih.
When invested,
he demoted Wu-chih's official rank, salary and garments.
Wu-chih harbored resentment over this.
In the fourth year (694 B.C.),
Duke Hua of Lu and his Lady went to Ch'i.
Previously, Duke Hsiang of Ch'i had secretly taken the Lady of Lu as a lover.
The Lady of Lu
was Duke Hsiang's younger sister.
In the time of Duke Hsi, she had been married off as Duke Huan of Lu's bride.
When Duke Huan came, Duke Hsiang again took her as a lover.
Duke Huan of Lu knew about it
and became angry with his Lady.
His Lady told this to Duke Hsiang of Ch'i.
He was drinking with the Lord of Lu
and got him drunk.
He had the strongman P'eng-sheng carry the Lord of Lu into his carriage,
and take advantage of this to crush Duke Huan to death.
When Duke Huan was taken down from the carriage he was dead.
The people of Lu upbraided [Ch'i],
and Duke Hsiang of Ch'i killed P'eng-sheng to apologize to Lu.
In the eighth year (690 B.C.),
Ch'i attacked Chi.
[The Marquis of] Chi moved and left his town.
In the twelfth year (686 B.C.).
Earlier Duke Hsiang sent Lien Ch'eng and
Kuang Chih-fu to garrison K'uei-ch'iu.
It was melon season when they went
and when there were melons [again] they were to be relieved.
They had been gone to garrison for one year,
it was the end of the melon season and the Duke had not sent out relief for them.
When someone requested relief for them,
the Duke did not consent to it.
For this reason, these two men grew angry
and took advantage of Noble Scion Wu-chih to plot rebellion.
Lien Ch'eng had a younger female cousin in the Duke's palace
who did not have his favor.
They had her spy on Duke Hsiang,
telling her,
"When our scheme succeeds, you will become Wu-chih's Lady."
In the winter in the twelfth month,
Duke Hsiang took an excursion to Ku-fen.
He then went hunting at P'ei-ch'iu.
When he saw a boar,
his attendant said,
"P'eng-sheng!"
The Duke became angry
and shot it.
The boar stood up like a man and wailed.
Terrified,
the Duke fell down from his carriage, injured his foot
and lost a hempen slipper.
When he returned home, he whipped the man in charge of hempen slippers, Fei, three hundred times.
Fei came out of the palace.
Because Wu-chih,
Lien Ch'eng
Kuan Chih-fu and the others had heard about the Duke's injury,
they led their people in a surprise attack on the palace.
They met the man in charge of hempen slippers, Fei,
who said,
"For now, do not enter and startle the palace.
If your startle the palace it will not be easy to enter."
Wu-chih did not believe him.
Fei showed them his wounds,
and then they believed him.
They waited outside the palace,
ordering Fei to enter ahead of them.
Fei went in first
and concealed Duke Hsiang behind a door.
After a long time,
Wu-chih and the others grew afraid
and entered the palace.
Fei, together with men from inside the palace and the Duke's favored vassals, unexpectedly attacked Wu-chih and the others.
They did not succeed
and all died.
Wu-chih entered the palace
and was unable to seek out the Duke.
Someone saw a man's feet behind the door.
They opened it to look,
and there was Duke Hsiang.
They then felled him
and Wu-chih invested himself as the Lord of Ch'i.
In the spring of the first year of Duke Huan (685 B.C.),
Wu-chih, the Lord of Ch'i, took an excursion to Yung-lin.
A person of Yung-lin had harbored resentment towards Wu-chih.
When he went out on the excursion,
the person of Yung-lin, making a surprise attack, killed Wu-Chih.
He told the Ch'i Grand Masters,
"Wu-chih cut down Duke Hsiang and invested himself.
Your vassal has respectfully carried out the punishment.
Only the Grand Masters will change the enthronement to a noble scion who should be invested.
I will listen only your orders."
Earlier,
Duke Hsiang had intoxicated and killed Duke Huan of Lu,
and he had taken Duke Huan's Lady as a lover.
He killed and punished innocent people several times,
acted lasciviously among women,
and made fools of his great vassals several times.
All the younger brothers feared that calamity would befall them.
For this reason, the next oldest brother, Chiu (d. 685 B.C.), fled to Lu.
His mother was a woman of Lu.
Kuan Chung (ca. 720–645 B.C.)
and Chao Hu (d. 685 B.C.) assisted him.
The next oldest brother, Hsiao-po, fled to Chü,
and Pao Shu assisted him.
Hsiao-po's mother
was a woman of Wey
who had had the favor of Duke Hsi (r. 730–698 B.C.).
Since his youth, Hsiao-po had been on very friendly terms with Grand Master Kao Hsi.
When the person of Yung-lin killed Wu-Chih
and discussed the enthronement of a ruler,
Kao and Kuo were the first to secretly summon Hsiao-po from Chü.
When [the Duke of] Lu heard about the death of Wu-chih,
he also sent out troops to escort the Noble Scion Chiu.
Moreover, he dispatched Kuan Chung to separately lead troops to block the road from Chü.
[Kuan Chung] shot an arrow that struck Hsiao-po's belt buckle.
Hsiao-po pretended to be dead,
and Kuan Chung dispatched a man to report to Lu as quickly as possible.
Those from Lu who were escorting Chiu moved even more slowly.
On the sixth day they arrived at Ch'i,
but Hsiao-po had already entered
and Kao Hsi had invested him.
He was Duke Huan (r. 685–643 B.C.).
Having been struck on the buckle,
Duke Huan pretended to be dead so as to deceive Kuan Chung.
Shortly after, he rode in an insulated carriage that moved as quickly as possible.
He also had the Kao
and Kuo [Clans] responding from within.
For these reasons, he was able to enter [the capital] first, become invested,
and send out troops to resist Lu.
In the autumn, [Ch'i] fought with Lu at Kan-shih.
The Lu troops were routed completely,
and the Ch'i troops obstructed them by cutting off the roads returning to their homes.
Ch'i sent Lu a letter, which read:
"Tzu Chiu is my brother.
I could not bear to punish him.
I would ask that Lu personally kill him.
and Kuan Chung are foes.
I would ask to take them and vent my resentment by making them into mincemeat.
If not,
we will besiege Lu."
The people of Lu were distressed by this,
and consequently killed Tzu Chiu in Sheng-Tou.
Shao Hu committed suicide,
and Kuan Chung asked to be imprisoned.
When Duke Huan came to the throne
and he sent out troops to attack Lu,
his heart's desire was to kill Kuan Chung.
Pao Shu-ya said:
"Your servant has fortunately been able to accompany you, my lord,
and you have finally taken the throne.
I do not have the means to further augment your honor, my lord.
If my lord wishes to rule Ch'i,
then Kao Hsi and Shu-ya will be sufficient.
But if my lord also wishes to serve as Hegemon to the King,
then you must have Kuan Yi-wu.
In whatever state Kuan Yi-wu resides, that state will become weighty.
We cannot lose him."
At this, Duke Huan went along with him.
Then he pretended to call Kuan Chung back to vent his resentment,
when he actually intended to employ him.
Kuan Chung understood this
and for this reason asked to go.
Pao Shu-ya went to receive Kuan Chung,
and when they reached T'ang-fu he released him from the foot manacles and hand chains.
After fasting and performing purgation rites, he met Duke Huan.
Duke Huan treated him with sumptuous ritual and, making him Grand Master,
entrusted his government to him.
After Duke Huan obtained Kuan Chung,
they worked together with Pao Shu,
Hsi P'eng and
Kao Hsi to cultivate the government of the state of Ch'i.
They joined together soldiers from every five families,
set up profits from light and heavy and from fish and salt
so as to relieve the poor and the destitute,
and rewarded the worthy and talented.
The people of Ch'i were all pleased.
In the second year (684 B.C.),
Ch'i attacked and destroyed T'an.
The Viscount of T'an took refuge in Chü.
Earlier, when Duke Huan had fled the state,
he passed through T'an
and [the Viscount of T'an] lacked proper courtesy.
For this reason he attacked T'an.
In the fifth year (681 B.C.),
Duke Huan attacked Lu,
and the troops of the Lu commander were defeated.
Duke Chuang of Lu (r. 693–662 B.C.) requested presenting Sui-yi to make peace.
Duke Huan consented
to meet with Lu at K'o and make a covenant.
The Duke of Lu was about to swear the covenant
when Ts'ao Mo used a dagger to coerce Duke Huan on the sacrificial altar mound.
Ts'ao Mo said,
"Return Lu's captured territories!"
Duke Huan consented to him,
and shortly after, Ts'ao Mo withdrew the dagger,
faced north, and took his place among the vassals.
Duke Huan was later filled with regret.
He intended not to give Lu the territories and to kill Ts'ao Mo.
Kuan Chung said,
"Now, you have been coerced to consent to him. If you break your word and kill him,
you would merely be seizing a solitary petty satisfaction.
However, if you abandon the trust of the feudal lords,
you will be losing the support of the world.
That will not do!"
After this, Duke Huan finally gave Lu the territories which Ts'ao Mo had lost in three defeats.
When the feudal lords learned of this,
they all trusted the Duke of Ch'i and wanted to give their loyalty to him.
In the seventh year (679 B.C.),
the feudal lords convened with Duke Huan at Chüan,
and at this point Duke Huan was first considered Hegemon by them.
In the fourteenth year (672 B.C.),
Duke Li of Ch'en's (r. 706–700 B.C.), son, Huan (705–? B.C.),
whose title was Ching-chung,
came to take refuge in Ch'i.
Duke Huan of Ch'i wanted to make him an Excellency,
but he declined. At that point, Duke Huan made him Head Officer of Artisans and Craftsman.
He was the ancestor of T'ien Ch'eng Tzu Ch'ang (fl. 484 B.C.).
In the twenty-third year (663 B.C.),
the Jung of the Mountains made a punitive expedition against Yen,
and Yen reported the danger to Ch'i.
Duke Huan of Ch'i went to Yen's rescue,
leading a punitive expedition against the Jung of the Mountains
and reaching Ku-chu before returning.
Duke Chuang of Yen (r. 690–658 B.C.) then escorted Duke Huan until they entered the Ch'i border.
Duke Huan said,
"Unless it is the Son of Heaven,
the feudal lords in seeing one another off do not leave their borders.
We cannot act without propriety towards Yen."
At this, he demarcated the land the Lord of Yen had reached with a ditch and gave it to Yen,
ordering the Lord of Yen to reinstate the government of Duke of Shao
and to pay tribute to Chou
as in the days of [Kings] Ch'eng (r. ca. 1067–1031 B.C.) and K'ang (r. ca. 1030–1005 B.C.).
When the feudal lords heard of this,
they all followed Ch'i.
The twenty-seventh year (659 B.C.):
The mother of Duke Min of Lu (r. 661–660 B.C.), who was called Ai Chiang,
was Duke Huan's younger sister
Ai Chiang had engaged in licentious behavior with Noble Scion Ch'ing-fu of Lu,
and Ch'ing-fu killed Duke Min.
Ai Chiang wanted to enthrone Ch'ing-fu,
but the people of Lu invested Duke Hsi (r. 659–627 B.C.) instead.
Duke Huan summoned Ai Chiang
and had her killed.
In the twenty-eighth year (658 B.C.),
Duke Wen of Wey (r. 659–635 B.C.) had suffered the strife of the Ti people
and informed Ch'i of his straits.
Ch'i led the feudal lords, built city walls at Ch'u-ch'iu and invested the Lord of Way [there].
In the twenty-ninth year (657 B.C.),
Duke Huan and his Lady, Belle Ts'ai, were frolicking in a boat.
Belle Ts'ai was adept in water
and she rocked the duke.
The duke became frightened
and went to stop her,
but she did not stop.
When the duke got out of the boat,
he was angry. He sent Belle Ts'ai back [to Ts'ai)
without divorcing her.
[The lord of] Ts'ai was also angry
and had the woman remarried.
Duke Huan heard of this and became angry.
He mobilized his forces and set out on a punitive expedition.
In the spring of the thirtieth year (656 B.C.),
Duke Huan of Ch'i led the feudal lords on a punitive expedition against Ts'ai
and [the populace of] Ts'ai dispersed.
Then they made a punitive attack against Ch'u.
King Ch'eng of Ch'u (r. 671–626 B.C.) mobilized his forces and asked,
"For what reason have you crossed into Our territory?"
Kuang Chung replied,
"Long ago, Duke K'ang of Chao ordered out Late Lord, T'ai-kung:
'As for the Five Feudal Lords and the Nine Chiefs,
you can actually chastise them
so as to support ans assist the House of Chou.'
He bestowed our Late Lord with [the right to] set foot east to the sea,
west to the Ho,
south to Mu-ling,
and north to Wu-ti.
Ch'u's tribute of bound reeds has not been presented,
and the royal sacrifices have not been supplied with it.
This is why we have to come in reproach.
[Moreover,] King Chao [of Chou] (r. ca. 1004–986 B.C.) went south on a punitive expedition and never returned.
This is why we have come to ask."
The King of Ch'u said,
"The tribute to them has not been presented;
it is true,
and it is Our offense.
We dare not but supply it.
As for King Chao's having left without returning,
your lordship might ask about it along the riverbanks."
[Then] the Ch'i forces advanced and were stationed at Hsing.
In the summer, the King of Ch'u sent Ch'ü Wan to lead troops to resist Ch'i.
The Ch'i forces retreated and were stationed at Shaolin.
Duke Huan boasted to Ch'ü Wan about their numerousness.
Ch'ü Wan said,
"If your lordship accords with the Way, then it may be possible.
If not,
then Ch'u will make Fang-ch'eng its city wall,
and the Chiang and the Han [Rivers] its moats.
How will your lordship be able to enter?"
Then Duke Huan made a covenant with Ch'ü Wan and left.
When they were passing through Ch'en,
Yüan T'ao-t'u of Ch'en deceived the Ch'i [forces].
He caused them to march out along the eastern regions
and [his deception] was discovered. In the autumn,
Ch'i launched a punitive expedition against Ch'en.
In this year (656 B.C.),
Chin killed Heir Shen Sheng.
In the summer of the thirty-fifth year (651 B.C.),
[Duke Huan] convened the feudal lords at K'uei-ch'iu (Sunflower Hillock).
King Hsiang of Chou (r. 651–620 B.C.) sent Steward K'ung to bestow Duke Huan with flesh from the sacrifices to Kings Wen and Wu,
a vermilion bow and arrows,
a grand sedan chariot,
and the order not to kneel and bow his head.
Duke Huan wanted to consent to this,
[but] Kuan Chung said,
"It would not do."
Then he descended, kneeled, bowed his head and received the bestowments.
In the fall, he again convened the feudal lords at K'uei-ch'iu
and took on a more arrogant appearance.
Chou sent Steward K'ung to participate.
There were some feudal lords who had deserted.
The Marquis of Chin was will
and, coming late, encountered Steward K'ung.
Steward K'ung said,
"The Marquis of Ch'i is arrogant.
Just do not go."
[The Marquis of Chin] went along with him.
In that year,
Duke Hsien of Chin (r. 676–651 B.C.) expired.
Li K'o killed Hsi Ch'i and
Chuo Tzu,
and Duke Mu of Ch'in (r. 659–621 B.C.), because of his lady, brought in Noble Scion Yi-wu as Lord of Chin.
At this, Duke Huan punished Chin for its chaos,
reaching Kao-liang.
He sent Hsi P'eng to enthrone the Lord of Chin
and returned home.
At that time, the House of Chou was in decline,
and only Ch'i,
Ch'u, Ch'in and
Chin had become strong.
When Chin was to first participate in the assemblies,
Duke Hsien died
and his state was thrown into civil chaos.
Duke Mu of Ch'in, being at a remote distance,
did not participate in the assemblies and covenants of the Central States.
King Ch'eng of Ch'u had first gathered Ching-Man under him,
establishing himself as an Yi or Ti.
Only Ch'i convened the assemblies and covenants of the Central States,
and Duke Huan was able to display his virtue.
For these reasons, the feudal lords had been assisted in hosting the assemblies.
Thereupon, Duke Huan proclaimed,
"We have led punitive expeditions south as far as Shao-ling,
and have performed the Wang Sacrifice to Mount Hsiung.
[We] have led punitive expeditions north against the Jung of the Mountains,
against Li-chih,
and against Ku-chu.
[We] have led punitive expeditions west against Ta Hsia (Great Hsia),
and have crossed Liu-sha (Drifting Sands).
[We] have harnessed the horses and hitched up the chariots, climbing the T'ai-hang
and reaching Mount Pi-erh before turning back.
Nonte of the feudal lords opposes Us.
We have convened assemblies of war chariots three times
and assemblies of passenger carriages six times,
calling the feudal lords together nine times
to unify and rectify the world.
Long ago, when the Three Dynasties received the Mandate,
how did they differ from this?
We wish to perform the Feng Sacrifice on Mount T'ai
and the Shan Sacrifice on Liang-fu."
Kuan Chung firmly admonished Duke Huan,
but he would not listen.
He then advised Duke Huan that only when precious and marvelous objects arrive from afar would he be able to perform the Feng Sacrifice.
Duke Huan then desisted.
In the thirty-eighth year (648 B.C.),
King Hsiang of Chou's younger brother, Tai (672–635 B.C.), joined with the Jung and
Ti in plotting to attack Chou.
Ch'i sent Kuan Chung to make a truce with the Jung for Chou.
Chou wanted to treat Kuan Chung with the ceremony appropriate for the highest ministers.
Kuan Chung touched his forehead to the ground and said,
"Your servant is the vassal of your liege.
How would I dare?"
He renounced it three times
and finally received the ceremony appropriate for lower-ranking ministers to have an audience [with Chou].
In the thirty-ninth year (647 B.C.),
King Hsiang of Chou's younger brother, Tai, came to take refuge in Ch'i.
Ch'i sent Chung-sun to petition the King,
apologizing on behalf of Tai.
King Hsiang was angered
and would not listen to him.
In the forty-first year (645 B.C.),
Duke Mu of Ch'in took Duke Hui of Chin (r. 650–637 B.C.) prisoner
and again restored him [to Chin].
In this year,
Kuan Chong and
Hsi P'eng both expired.
When Kuan Chung was ill,
Duke Huan asked,
"Of all the assembled vassals, who is the one who would do as a Prime Minister?"
Kuan Chung replied,
"No one knows his vassals better than the lord."
The Duke said,
"What about Yi-ya?"
[Kuan Chung] responded,
"He killed his son so as to please my lord.
This is not the nature of human emotions.
He will not do."
The Duke said,
"What about K'ai Fang?"
[Kuan Chung] responded,
"He turned his back on his relatives so as to please my lord.
It will be difficult to get close to him."
This is not the nature of human emotions.
The Duke said,
"What about Page Tiao?"
[Kuan Chung] responded,
"He castrated himself so as to please my lord.
This is not the nature of human emotions.
It will be difficult to become intimate with him."
Kuan Chung died,
but Duke Huan did not make use of Kuan Chung's words.
In the end he made close use of these three men,
and it was these three men who monopolized authority.
In the forty-second year (644 B.C.),
the Jung attacked Chou.
Chou informed Ch'i of its straits.
Ch'i ordered each of the feudal lords to send forth troops to guard Chou.
In this year,
Noble Scion Ch'ung-erh of Chin came.
Duke Huan gave him a wife.
In the forty-third year (643 B.C.).
Earlier, none of Duke Huan of Ch'i's three Ladies-
Belle Wang,
Belle Hsü or
Belle Ts'ai-
had a son.
Duke Huan loved his harem,
and there were many in the harem who were favorites.
There were six who were like Ladies to him:
Belle Wey the Elder
bore Wu-kuei (d. 642 B.C.);
Belle Wey the Younger
bore Yüan, [the future] Duke Hui (r. 608–599 B.C.);
Belle Cheng
bore Chao, [the future] Duke Hsiao (r. 642–633 B.C.);
Ko Ying
bore P'an, [the future] Duke Chao (r. 632–613 B.C.);
Belle Mi
bore Shang-jen, [the future] Duke Yi (r. 612–609 B.C.);
and Sung Hua Tzu
bore Noble Scion Yung.
Duke Huan and Kuan Chung had entrusted [the future] Duke Hsiao to Duke Hsiang of Song (r. 650–637 B.C.)
and had made him the Heir.
Yung Wu, who had favor with Belle Kung of Wey,
presented lavish gifts to Duke Huan through the eunuch, Page Tiao,
and, also gained his favor.
He received Duke Huan's consent to establish Wu-kuei.
After Kuan Chung expired,
the five Noble Scions all sought the throne.
In the winter, on the yi-hai day of the tenth month,
Duke Huan of Ch'i expired.
Yi-ya entered [the palace],
and together with Page Tiao, took advantage of the harem favorites to kill all of the various functionaries
and enthrone Noble Scion Wu-kuei as Lord.
Chao, the Heir, fled to Sung.
When Duke Huan became ill,
the five Noble Scions each formed coteries to struggle for the throne.
When Duke Huan expired,
they finally attacked one another.
For this reason, the palace was empty,
and none dared encoffin [the corpse of Duke Huan].
Duke Huan's corpse was on his bed for sixty-seven days,
and corpse insects come out from under the door.
On the yi-hai day of the twelfth month (11 November 643 B.C.),
Wu-kuei was invested.
After this, [Duke Huan's corpse] was unconfined and his death was announced.
On the night of the hsin-ssu day (17 November),
there were ceremonies of dressing the corpse and laying out the coffin for burial.
Duke Huan had over ten sons.
In total, there were five who afterwards were invested.
Wu-kuei was invested for three months and died
without a posthumous title.
Next there was Duke Hsiao,
then Duke Chao,
after that Duke Yi,
and then Duke Hui.
In the third month of the first year of Duke Hsiao (642 B.C.),
Duke Hsiang of Sung led the troops of the feudal lords, escorting Heir Chao of Ch'i on a punitive campaign against Ch'i.
The people of Ch'i were fearful
and killed their Lord Wu-kuei.
The people of Ch'i were about to enthrone Heir Chao
when the followers of the four noble scions attacked the Heir.
The Heir hastened to Sung,
and Sung then gave battle to the four noble scions of Ch'i.
In the fifth month,
Sung defeated the forces of the four noble scions of Ch'i, and invested Heir Chao.
He was Duke Hsiao of Ch'i (r. 642–633 B.C.).
Duke Huan and Kuan Chung had entrusted Sung with the Heir,
and for this reason Sung came on a punitive campaign against [the four noble scions of Ch'i].
Because of the chaos,
it was in the eighth month that Duke Huan of Ch'i was finally buried.
In the spring of the sixth year (637 B.C.),
Ch'i led an expedition against [the Duke of] Sung
because he did not join in making a covenant with Ch'i.
In the summer, Duke Hsiang of Sung expired.
In the seventh year (636 B.C.),
Duke Wen of Chin (r. 636–628 B.C.) was invested.
In the tenth year (633 B.C.),
Duke Hsiao expired.
Duke Hsiao's younger brother, P'an took advantage of Noble Scion K'ai Fang of Wey to kill Duke Hsiao's son and enthrone P'an.
He was Duke Chao (r. 632–613 B.C.).
Duke Hsiao [sic!]
was a son of Duke Huan,
and his mother was called Ko Ying.
In the first year of Duke Chao (632 B.C.),
Duke Wen of Chin defeated Ch'u at Ch'eng-p'u.
He also convened the feudal lords at Chien-t'u
and had an audience with Chou.
The Son of Heaven had Chin proclaimed Hegemon.
In the sixth year (627 B.C.),
the Ti invaded Ch'i,
Duke Wen of Chin expired,
and Ch'in soldiers were defeated at Hsiao.
In the twelfth year (621 B.C.),
Duke Mu of Ch'in (r. 659–621 B.C.) expired.
In the fifth month of the nineteenth year (614 B.C.),
Duke Chao expired.
His son, She, was invested as the Lord of Ch'i.
She's mother did not have the favor of Duke Chao,
and none of the people of the capital were in awe [of him].
Because when Duke Huan died, Duke Chao's younger brother, Shang-jen, had struggled for the throne without obtaining it, at the death of Duke Huan,
he secretly associated with worthy gentlemen,
gave support to and cherished the families of the hundred cognomens,
and the families of the hundred cognomens were pleased.
When Duke Chao expired,
his son She was invested.
He was isolated and weak.
[Shang-jen] then joined with his host in the tenth month, cut down the Ch'i Lord She right on the tomb [of his father, Duke Chao],
and Shang-jen invested himself.
He was Duke Yi (r. 612–609).
Duke Yi
was Duke Huan's son.
His mother was called Belle Mi.
In the spring of the fourth year of Duke Yi (609 B.C.).
Earlier, when Duke Yi had been Noble Scion,
he went hunting with the father of Ping Jung.
[Duke Yi] fought over the catch, but did not prevail.
When he ascended the throne,
he cut off the feet of Ping Jung's father
and made Ping Jung his chariot driver.
Yung Chih's wife was beautiful.
The Duke brought her into the palace
and made Yung Chih Right Outrider.
In the fifth month,
Duke Yi took an excursion to Shen-ch'ih (Shen Pools).
The two men were bathing
and joking. [Yung] Chih said,
[Ping] Jung said,
"[You are] the son of cut-off feet!"
"[You're the one] whose wife was snatched away!"
The two men, both sickened by these words,
subsequently harbored resentment.
They plotted to take an excursion together with the Duke among the bamboos.
The two men assassinated Duke Yi in his chariot,
abandoned him among the bamboos, and fled away from the state.
After Duke Yi's enthronement,
he became arrogant and the commoners did not give their support.
The people of Ch'i removed his son, welcomed Noble Scion Yüan in Wey,
and invested him.
He was Duke Hui (r. 608–599 B.C.).
Duke Hui
was the son of Duke Huan.
His mother was a woman of Wey
and was called Belle Wey the Younger.
They had been avoiding the chaos in Ch'i
and, for this reason, they were in Wey.
In the second year of Duke Hui (607 B.C.),
a Ch'ang-Ti (Long Ti) came.
Wang-tzu Ch'eng-fu attacked and killed him,
and buried him at the north gate.
Chao Ch'uan of Chin assassinated his lord, Duke Ling (r. 620–607 B.C.).
In the tenth year (599 B.C.),
Duke Hui expired.
His son, Wu-yeh, Duke Ch'ing (r. 598–582 B.C.), was invested.
Earlier, Tsui Chu had the favor of Duke Hui.
When Duke Hui expired,
the Kao and Kuo [clans] feared his coercion
and drove him out.
Ts'ui Chu fled to Wey.
In the first year of Duke Ch'ing (598 B.C.),
King Chuang of Ch'u (r. 613–591 B.C.) was powerful
and launched an expedition against Ch'en.
In the second year (597 B.C.),
he besieged Cheng,
and the Earl of Cheng surrendered.
Shortly thereafter, [King Chuang] returned the state to the Earl of Cheng.
In the spring of the sixth year (593 B.C.),
Chin sent Hsi K'o to Ch'i.
[The Duke of] Ch'i had Ladies observe him from among the curtains.
As Hsi K'o climbed [the steps],
the Ladies laughed at him.
Hsi K'o said,
"If I do not repay [this insult],
I will not cross the Ho again!"
When he returned, he requested to lead an expedition against Ch'i.
The Marquis of Chin did not consent to him.
When Ch'i envoys arrived in Chin,
Hsi K'o seized the four Ch'i envoys at Ho-nei
and killed them.
In the eighth year (591 B.C.),
Chin launched an expedition against Ch'i.
Ch'i had Noble Scion Ch'iang become a hostage in Chin,
and the Chin troops withdrew.
In the spring of the tenth year (589 B.C.),
Ch'i lead expeditions against Lu and
Wey.
Grand Masters of Lu and Wey went to Chin to ask for troops.
Everything went through Hsi K'o.
Chin sent Hsi K'o with eight hundred teams of chariots as Commander of the Central Army.
Shih Hsieh commanded the Upper Army
and Luan Shu commanded the Lower Army
so as to rescue Lu and
Wey and lead an expedition against Ch'i.
On the jen-shen day of the sixth month,
they encountered the Marquis of Ch'i's soldiers at the foot of [Mount] Mi-chi.
On the kuei-yu day,
they drew up their ranks at An.
P'ang Ch'ou-fu was Duke Ch'ing of Ch'i's Right Outrider.
Duke Ch'ing said,
"Charge them!
Defeat the Chin army and we will assemble to feast!"
[The Duke] shot [an arrow] and wounded Hsi K'o,
and blood flowed down to his sandals.
K'o wanted to go back into the barricade.
His chariot driver said,
"When I first entered [the battleground],
I was wounded twice,
[but] I did not dare to speak about my afflictions.
I feared it would terrify the officers and the foot soldiers.
I hope that you, Sir, will endure it."
Then they again gave battle.
When giving battle, Ch'i was in dire straits,
and [P'ang] Ch'ou-fu feared the Marquis of Ch'i would be taken.
Hence they changed places,
with Duke Ch'ing as the Right Outrider.
When the chariot became entangled in a tree and stopped,
the Chin Junior Commander Han Chüeh prostrated himself before the Marquis of Ch'i's chariot
and said,
"My lord has sent his vassals to rescue Lu and
joking with him.
Ch'ou-fu had Duke Ch'ing get off [the chariot] to get something to drink.
Taking the opportunity, he was able to flee
and escape
in among his army.
Hsi K'o of Chin wanted to kill [P'ang] Ch'ou-fu.
Ch'ou-fu said,
"If I take the place of my lord in death and am slaughtered,
those who are vassals afterward will have no loyalty to their lords!"
K'o spared him,
and Ch'ou-fu consequently was able to flee back to Ch'i.
At this point, the Chin armies pursued Ch'i all the way to Ma-ling.
The Marquis of Ch'i asked to apologize with precious objects.
[Chin] would not listen,
and was determined to obtain Hsiao T'ung Shu Tzu, who had laughed at [Hsi] K'o.
[Chin also] ordered that Ch'i lay out its fields eastwards.
[The Ch'i envoy] replied,
"Shu Tzu
is the Lord of Ch'i's mother.
The Lord of Ch'i's mother is indeed no different than the Lord of Chin's mother.
How can you, Sir, deal with her?
Moreover, you, Sir, punish with righteousness but conclude with cruelty.
How can this be permissible?"
At that, [Chin] then consented,
ordering that [Ch'i] return
the invaded territories to Lu and Wey.
In the eleventh year (588 B.C.),
Chin first established the Six Ministers
in reward for their accomplishments at An.
Duke Ch'ing of Ch'i paid his respects at the Chin court.
He wanted to honor Duke Ching of Chin (r. 599–581 B.C.) as king.
Duke Ching of Chin did not dare to accept.
