[The Duke of Ch'i] subsequently returned home.
When he returned, Duke Ch'ing opened the gardens and menageries,
lightened taxes and collections,
offered relief to the orphans, asked after the sick,
and emptied accumulated items in his storehouses to aid people.
The people were also greatly pleased.
[Duke Ch'ing] treated the feudal lords with sumptuous ritual.
In the end when Duke Ch'ing expired,
the families of the hundred cognomens supported him
and the feudal lords did not oppose him.
In the seventeenth year (582 B.C.),
Duke Ch'ing expired,
and his son Huan, Duke Ling (r. 581–554 B.C.), was invested.
In the ninth year of Duke Ling (573 B.C.),
Luan Shu of Chin cut down his lord, Duke Li (r. 580–573 B.C.).
In the tenth year (572 B.C.),
Duke Tao of Chin (r. 572–558 B.C.) launched an expedition against Ch'i,
and Ch'i ordered Noble Scion Kuang to become a hostage in Chin.
In the nineteenth year (563 B.C.),
[Duke Ling] established his son, Kuang, as Heir,
and Kao Hou tutored him.
They were ordered to assemble with the feudal lords to make a covenant in Chung-li.
In the twenty-seventh year (555 B.C.),
Chin sent Chung-hang Hsien Tzu leading an expedition against Ch'i.
The Ch'i troops were defeated.
Duke Ling ran and entered Lin-tzu.
When Yen Ying (d. ca. 500 B.C.) stopped Duke Ling,
Duke Ling did not heed him.
[Yen Ying] said,
"My lord certainly has no courage!"
The Chin forces then besieged Lin-tzu,
and the guards defending the Lin-tzu city walls did not dare to come out.
Chin burned the outer city walls and withdrew.
In the twenty-eighth year (554 B.C.).
Earlier, Duke Ling took a woman of Lu in marriage
and bore a son, Kuang,
making him the heir.
[Duke Ling had two consorts] Belle Chung and
Belle Jung.
Belle Jung was the favorite;
Belle Chung bore a son, Ya,
and entrusted him to Belle Jung.
Belle Jung requested that he be made heir,
and the Duke consented to this.
Belle Chung said,
"That will not do.
Kuang's establishment
is ranked among the feudal lords.
Now if you remove him with our reason,
my lord will surely regret it."
The Duke said,
"It is up to me only."
Then, he sent Heir Kuang east,
and had Kao Hou mentor Ya as Heir.
When Duke Ling became sick,
Ts'ui Chu went to meet the former Heir, Kuang, to establish him.
This was Duke Chuang (r. 553–548 B.C.).
On the jen-ch'en day of the fifth month,
Duke Chuang killed Belle Jung.
Duke Ling expired.
Duke Chuang ascended the throne.
He seized Heir Ya on the Hillock of Kou-tou (Crooked Hole)
and killed him.
In the eighth month,
Ts'ui Chu killed Kao Hou.
Chin heard about the chaos in Ch'i,
and launched an expedition against Ch'i
that reached Kao-t'ang.
In the third year of Duke Chuang (551 B.C.),
Chin Grand Master Luan Ying fled to Ch'i.
Duke Chuang treated him lavishly as his guest.
Yen Ying and
T'ien Wen Tzu admonished,
[but] the Duke would not listen to them.
In the fourth year (550 B.C.),
Duke Chuang of Ch'i sent Luan Ying to secretly enter Ch'ü-wo to collaborate from within.
[The Duke] employed soldiers to follow him,
climbing the T'ai-hang
and entering Meng-men.
Luan Ying was defeated,
and the Ch'i soldiers turned back
and took Chao-ko (Morning Sun).
In the sixth year (548 B.C.).
Earlier, the Master of T'ang's wife was beautiful,
and when the Master of T'ang died,
Ts'ui Chu took her in marriage.
Duke Chuang took her as a lover,
going many times to the Ts'ui household.
[Once] he took Ts'ui Chu's cap and presented it to someone else.
An attendant said,
"That will not do."
Ts'ui Chu became angry
and, by taking advantage of the Duke's having launched a campaign against Chin,
intended to plot together with Chin to launch a surprise attack on Ch'i. However, he was not able to find an opportunity.
Duke Chuang had once caned the eunuch Chia Chü.
Chia Chü, who continued to wait on [the Duke],
spied on the Duke for Ts'ui Chu so as to avenge his grievance.
In the fifth month,
the Viscount of Chü paid a court visit to Ch'i,
and Ch'i feasted him on the chia-hsü day (25 April 548 B.C.).
Ts'ui Chu claimed illness and did not see to the affair.
On the yi-hai day (26 April),
the Duke asked about Ts'ui Chu's illness
and then went after Ts'ui Chu's wife.
Ts'ui Chu's wife entered a room,
shut herself up behind the door with Ts'ui Chu, and did not come out.
The Duke leaned against a pillar, singing.
The eunuch, Chia Chü, intercepted the Duke's accompanying officials, entered,
and shut the gate.
Ts'ui Chu's followers came out from inside holding weapons.
The Duke climbed a terrace and asked to be released.
They did not consent.
He asked to make a covenant,
and they did not consent.
The Duke asked to commit suicide in the [ancestral] temple,
and they did not consent.
They all said,
"The Lord's vassal, [Ts'ui] Chu is extremely ill
and unable to listen to orders.
This is near the Duke's palace,
and these vassals of your liege struggle to seize those who are licentious.
We are not aware of a second order."
The Duke was climbing over a wall
when an arrow was shot that hit him in the thigh.
The Duke fell down backwards,
and they then killed him.
Yen Ying stood outside Ts'ui Chu's gate
and said,
"If a lord dies for the sake of the altars of soil and grain, then one must die with him.
If he flees for the sake of the altars of soil and grain, then one most flee with him.
If he dies for his own sake or flees for his own sake,
then except for his private intimates,
who would venture to bear the responsibility with him?"
The gate opened and he entered,
pillowed the Duke's corpse and wept over it.
He performed the ritual three leaps and went out.
Someone said to Ts'ui Chu,
"We must kill him."
Ts'ui Chu said,
"The people look up to him.
By sparing him, I will win over the people."
On the ting-ch'ou day,
Ts'ui Chu invested Ch'u-chiu, Duke Chuang's younger half-brother.
He was Duke Ching (r. 547–490 B.C.).
Duke Ching's mother
was a daughter of Shu-sun Hsüan-po of Lu.
Duke Ching was invested,
and he employed Ts'ui Chu as Prime Minister of the Right
and Ch'ing Feng as Prime Minister of the Left.
The two Prime Ministers, fearful that chaos would break out,
then made a covenant with the people of the capital, which read:
"Those who are not with Ts'ui [Chu] and Ch'ing [Feng] shall die."
Yen Tzu looked up to heaven and said,
"I, Ying, will not be caught up in this. It is only those who are loyal to the lord and who benefit the altars of soil and grain that I follow."
He refused to make to covenant.
Ch'ing Feng intended to kill Yen Tzu.
Ts'ui Chu said,
"He is a loyal vassal.
Let us spare him."
The Grand Scribe of Ch'i wrote:
"Ts'ui Chu cut down Duke Chuang."
Ts'ui Chu killed him.
His younger brother wrote it again,
and Ts'ui Chu also killed him.
When the youngest brother wrote it again,
then Ts'ui Chu spared him.
In the first year of Duke Ching (547 B.C.).
Earlier, Ts'ui Chu begot two sons, Ch'eng and Ch'iang.
After their mother died,
he took the Tung-kuo woman in marriage,
who bore Ming.
The Tung-duo woman caused [T'ang] Wu-chiu, her former husband's son, and Yen, her younger brother, to assist the Ts'ui Clan.
Ts'ui Ch'eng committed an offense,
and the two assistants punished him swiftly
and established [Ts'ui] Ming as Heir.
[Ts'ui] Ch'eng asked to retire to Ts'ui,
and Ts'ui Chu consented to him.
The two assistants would not hear of it
and said,
"Ts'ui
is the ancestral town.
It would not do."
[Ts'ui] Ch'eng and [Ts'ui] Ch'iang were angry
and reported to Ch'ing Feng.
There was bad blood between Ch'ing Feng and Ts'ui Chu,
and [Ch'ing Feng] wanted him defeated.
[Ts'ui] Ch'eng and [Ts'ui] Ch'iang killed Wu-chiu and
Yen in Ts'ui Chu's house,
and the entire family fled.
Ts'ui Chu became angry and,
as more of his men were there,
he had a eunuch drive him
to see Ch'ing Feng.
Ch'ing Feng said,
"Allow me to execute them for you, Sir."
He sent Ts'ui Chu's enemy, Lu-p'u P'ieh, to attack the Ts'ui Clan,
killing Ch'eng and
Ch'iang, and wiping out the entire Ts'ui Clan.
Ts'ui Chu's wife committed suicide.
Ts'ui Chu, having no home to return to,
also committed suicide.
Ch'ing Feng became the State Prime Minister
and monopolized authority.
In the tenth month of the third year (545 B.C.),
Ch'ing Feng went out hunting.
Earlier, Ch'ing Feng, having already killed Ts'ui Chu,
became more and more arrogant.
He was fond of wine, loved hunting,
and did not heed the administration of government orders.
Ch'ing She exercised the administration of the government,
and there were already grudges against him.
T'ien Wen Tzu spoke to Huan Tzu, and said,
"Rebellion is about to be instigated."
The T'ien, Pao,
Kao and Luan Clans plotted with one another against the Ch'ing Cla.
Ch'ing She sent out armored soldiers to surround Ch'ing Feng's palace,
and the followers of the four families jointly attacked and defeated them.
After Ch'ing Feng returned
and was unable to enter,
he fled to Lu.
The people of Ch'i reproached Lu,
and [Ch'ing] Feng fled to Wu.
Wu gave him Chu-fang,
and he gathered together his clansmen and settled them there.
He became richer than when he was in Ch'i.
In that fall,
the people of Ch'i removed and buried Duke Chuang,
and exposed Ts'ui Chu's corpse in the marketplace so as to please the multitude.
In the ninth year (539 B.C.),
Duke Ching sent Yen Ying to Chin,
where he spoke together privately with Shu Hsiang, saying,
"The government of Ch'i will finally turn to the T'ian Clan.
Although the T'ien Clan lacks any great virtue,
they use public authority for [the people's] personal interests,
they have done good deeds for the people,
and the people love them."
In the twelfth year (536 B.C.),
Duke Ching went to Chin
to see Duke P'ing (r. 557–532 B.C.),
intending to launch an expedition against Yen with him.
In the eighteenth year (530 B.C.),
the Duke again went to Chin
to see Duke Chao (r. 531–526 B.C.).
In the twenty-sixth year (522 B.C.),
he went hunting in the outskirts of Lu
and took the opportunity to enter Lu
to ask about the social codes of Lu together with Yen Ying.
In the thirty-first year (517 B.C.),
Duke Chao of Lu (r. 541–510 B.C.), avoiding the troubles [caused by] the Chi Clan,
took refuge in Ch'i.
Ch'i wanted to enfeoff him with one thousand she.
Tzu Chia stopped Duke Chao,
and Duke Chao then asked Ch'i to launch an expedition against Lu.
They took Yen and with it housed Duke Chao.
In the thirty-second year (516 B.C.),
a comet appeared.
Duke Ching, sitting in the Po-ch'in (Cypress Chamber [Terrace]),
sighed and said,
"Such a magnificent hall!
Who will possess this?"
The assembled vassals all wept.
Yen Tzu laughed
and the Duke was angered.
Yen Tzu said,
"Your servant was laughing at the assembled vassals' extreme flattery."
Duke Ching said,
"The comet appeared in the northeast
right in Ch'i's district field.
We, the Lonely One, think this is worrisome."
Yen Tzu said,
"My lord has elevated the terraces and deepened the pools.
You have taxed and collected as if you would not get anything from [the people],
and have punished and penalized out of fear of not triumphing over them.
If the Pei star [as a harbinger of distaster [sic!]] is going to appear,
why be afraid of a [regular] comet?"
The Duke said,
"Would it do to perform the jang sacrifice, or not?"
Yan Ying said,
"If an invocation could cause deities to come,
the jang sacrifice could cause them to disappear.
[However,] the families of the hundred cognomens who suffer and harbor resentment number in the tens of thousands.
Yet my lord orders a single person to perform the jang sacrifice to it [the comet].
How could this triumph over the mouths of the multitude?"
At that time, Duke Ching was fond of building palaces and residences,
and of collecting dogs and horses.
He was wasteful and extravagant,
taxed heavily, and increased the severity of his punishments.
For these reasons, Yen Tzu admonished him like this.
In the forty-second year (506 B.C.),
Ho-lü, the King of Wu, led an expedition against Ch'u
and entered Ying.
In the forty-seventh year (501 B.C.),
Yang Hu of Lu attacked his lord.
When he did not triumph,
he fled to Ch'i
and asked that Ch'i launch an expedition against Lu.
Pao Tzu admonished Duke Ching,
who then imprisoned Yang Hu.
Yang Hu was able to escape
and flee to Chin.
In the forty-eighth year (500 B.C.),
[Duke Ching] held a friendly meeting with Duke Ting of Lu (r. 509–495 B.C.) at Chia-ku (Narrow Valley).
Li Chü said [to Duke Ching],
"K'ung Ch'iu (551–479 B.C.) understands ritual, but is cowardly.
I request that you order the Lai people to make music,
take the opportunity to seize the Lord of Lu,
and we can realize our ambitions."
Duke Ching, envious that K'ung Ch'iu was the Prime Minister of Lu,
feared it [Lu] would become Hegemon.
For this reason, he followed Li Chu's plan.
Just as the meeting started,
[Ch'i] presented the Lai music.
K'ung Tzu went up the steps without pausing,
had the authorities concerned seize the Lai people and behead them
while he reproached Duke Ching with ritual.
Duke Ching was mortified,
and then returning Lu's captured territories to apologize,
dismissed [the meeting] and left.
In this year,
Yan Ying expired.
In the fifty-fifth year (493 B.C.),
the Fan and Chung-hang [Clans] revolted against their lord in Chin.
Chin attacked them severely,
and they came to ask for grain.
T'ien Ch'i, intending to rebel,
set up a coterie of treacherous vassals.
He advised Duke Ching, saying,
"The Fan and
Chung-hang [Clans] have done favors for Ch'i several times.
You cannot but go to their aid."
Then [Duke Ching] sent [T'ien] Ch'i to go to their aid and transport grain to them.
In the summer of the fifty-eighth year (490 B.C.),
the legitimate heir, the son of Duke Ching's Lady, Belle Yen, died.
Duke Ching's favorite concubine, Belle Jui, had given birth to a son, Shu.
Shu was young,
his mother was lowly
and had no standard of conduct.
All the grand masters, afraid of his becoming successor,
then said they hoped an older and worthier one would be selected from among the sons to be made heir.
Duke Ching was old,
and he loathed any talk about the matter of succession.
Moreover, he loved Shu's mother
and wanted to establish him,
[but] he dreaded speaking out about it.
Then he spoke to all the grand masters, saying,
"Just make merry.
How will the state be in dismay over having no lord?"
In the fall, Duke Ching became ill.
He ordered Kuo Hui Tzu and
Kao Chao Tzu to establish the younger son, Shu, as Heir,
and to drive out the other assembled noble scions
and move them to Lai.
When Duke Ching expired,
Heir Shu was invested,
and he was Yen Ju Tzu (r. 489 B.C.).
In the winter, [the Duke] was not yet buried;
all the noble scions, fearing execution,
went out [of Ch'i] into exile.
Among Shu's various older brothers born of different mothers were noble scions Shou,
Chü, and Ch'ien, who fled to Wey;
noble scions Chü and
Yang-sheng fled to Lu.
The Lai people sung about this, saying:
Duke Ching had died! The burial was held without you.
The events of the three armies! The planning was [done] without you.
The crowd of you! The crowd of you!
To what faction are you to go?
In the spring of the first year of Yen Ju Tzu (489 B.C.),
T'ien Ch'i pretended to serve the Kao and
Kuo [Clans].
Whenever they paid a court visit
[T'ien] Ch'i would be the Right Outrider
and talk to them, saying,
"You, Sirs, have obtained the Lord.
The grand masters all feel themselves in danger
and intend to plot to make rebellion."
He would also speak with the various grand master, saying,
"Kao Chao Tzu is fearsome.
Before he starts anything,
you should act in advance of him."
The grand masters followed him.
In the sixth month,
T'ieh Ch'i and
Pao Mu then together with the grand masters led soldiers into the Duke's palace
to mount an attack on Kao Chao Tzu.
When [Kao] Chao Tzu heard about this,
he went together with Kuo Hui Tzu to the Duke's aid.
The Duke's forces were defeated.
T'ien Ch'i's followers pursued them,
and Kuo Hui Tzu fled to Chü.
They then turned around and killed Kao Chao Tzu.
Yen Yü fled to Lu.
In the eighth month,
Ping Yi-tzu of Ch'i [also fled to Lu].
After T'ien Ch'i defeated the two Prime Ministers,
he then sent someone to go to Lu to summon Noble Scion Yang-sheng.
Yang-sheng went to Ch'i,
and secretly hid in T'ien Ch'i's household.
On the wu-tzu day of the tenth month,
T'ien Ch'i invited the various grand masters, saying,
"Ch'ang's mother will offer sacrifices with fish and beans.
Please be kind enough to come meet and drink."
When they met and were drinking,
T'ien Ch'i put Yang-sheng in a sack
and placed it on a seat.
When he opened the sack and Yang-sheng came out,
he said,
"This is the Lord of Ch'i!"
The grand masters all knelt and paid homage.
When [T'ien Ch'i] was about to make a covenant with the grand masters and enthrone him (Yang-sheng),
Pao Mu was drunk,
and T'ien Ch'i falsely said to the grand masters,
"I have schemed together with Pao Mu to enthrone Yang-sheng."
Pao-mu [sic!] became angry, and said,
"Sir, do you forget the orders of Duke Ching?"
The various grand masters looked at one another, intending to show regret,
when Yang-sheng came forward,
struck his forehead against the ground, and said,
"If it will do, then enthrone me.
If not, then that will be the end of it."
Pao Mu, afraid that calamity would arise,
then also said,
"They are both sons of Duke Ching.
What would be wrong with it?"
He then participated in the covenant
to enthrone Yang-sheng.
This was Duke Tao (r. 488–485 B.C.).
When Duke Tao entered the palace,
he sent someone to move Yen Ju Tzu to T'ai,
kill him in a tent,
and drive out Ju Tzu's mother, Jui Tzu.
Jui Tzu's status had formerly been lowly, and Ju Tzu was young.
For these reasons, they had no authority,
and the people of the capital held them lightly.
In the first year of Duke Tao (488 B.C.),
Ch'i launched an expedition against Lu,
taking Huan and
Ch'an. Earlier,
when Yang-sheng was in exile in Lu,
Chi K'ang Tzu married his younger sister to him.
When he returned and ascended the throne,
he sent an envoy to receive her.
Belle Chi had taken Chi Fang-you as a lover,
and had spoken forth of what was in their hearts.
Lu did not dare give her to him [Yang-sheng].
For this reason, Ch'i launched an expedition against Lu,
and in the end received Belle Chi.
Belle Chi was favored,
and Ch'i again returned Lu's captured territories.
There was bad blood between Pao Tzu and Duke Tao,
and they were not on good terms.
In the fourth year (485 B.C.),
when Wu and Lu led an expedition to the southern regions of Ch'i,
Pao Tzu cut down Duke Tao
and sent a funeral notice to Wu.
Fu-ch'ai, the King of Wu (r. 495–473 B.C.), wept for three days outside the gate of his military camp,
and was going to enter from the sea to punish Ch'i.
The people of Ch'i defeated them,
and then the Wu forces withdrew.
Chao Yang of Chin led an expedition against Ch'i,
and arrived at Lai before withdrawing.
The people of Ch'i together invested Duke Tao's son, Jen,
and he was Duke Chien (r. 484–481 B.C.).
In the spring of the fourth year of Duke Chien (481 B.C.).
Earlier, when Duke Chien and his father, Yang-sheng, were both in Lu together,
K'an Chih had their favor.
When [Duke Chien] ascended the throne,
he had K'an Chih administer the government.
T'ien Cheng Tzu was afraid of him,
and turned his head around to look at him several times in court.
The chariot driver, [T'ien] Yang, talked with Duke Chien, and said,
"T'ien and
K'an cannot continue together.
My lord must choose between them."
Duke Chien would not listen to him.
When Tzu-wo was going to court at night,
T'ien Ni killed a man.
[Tzu-wo] encountered him,
then apprehended him, and took him into [the court].
At the time, the T'ien Clan was harmonious.
They had the prisoner [claim] illness and gave the prison guard wine.
[T'ien Ni] intoxicated and killed the guard,
and was able to flee.
Tzu-wo made a covenant with the T'iens at the Ch'en Clan household.
Earlier, T'ien Pao, intending to become Tzu-wo's minister,
sent Kung-sun to speak about [T'ien Pao].
[T'ien] Pao had a death [of someone close], and [Kung-sun] stopped.
Later, he finally was considered a minister,
and he won the favor of Tzu-wo.
Tzu-wo spoke to [him] and said,
"If I were to drive out all of the T'ien Clan and establish you,
would it do?"
He replied,
"I am remote from the T'ien Clan.
Moreover, those who oppose you are no more than a few people.
Then he reported to the T'ien Clan.
Tzu-hsing said,
"He has obtained the Lord.
If we do not act in advance of him,
it will be sure to bring calamity to you, Sir."
Tzu-hsing [then] lodged in the Duke's palace.
In the super on the jen-shen day of the fifth month (26 April 481 B.C.),
Ch'eng Tzu and his older and younger brothers went in four chariots to the Duke.
Tzu-wo was in the pavilion,
and came out to receive them.
They then entered [the palace]
and shut the gate.
A eunuch resisted them,
and Tzu-hsing killed the eunuch.
The Duke was drinking wine with women in the T'an-t'ai (Sandalwood Terrace).
Ch'eng Tzu moved him to a bedchamber.
The Duke, holding a pole-axe, was about to attack him
when Grand Scribe Tzu Yü said,
"It will not be disadvantageous.
He is about to do away with that which causes you harm."
Ch'eng Tzu went out and lodged in the armory.
When he heard the Duke was still angry,
he was about to go out,
and he said,
"What place does not have a lord?"
Tzu-hsing drew his sword and said,
"Hesitation
is the traitor of all affairs.
Who is not a T'ien clansman?
Whoever does not kill you, Sir, would not be like a T'ien clansman."
Ch'eng Tzu then desisted.
Tzu-wo returned home,
collected followers, and attacked the side (?) and main gates.
When they all did not prevail over them,
they then went back out,
and the T'ien Clan pursued them.
People in Feng-ch'iu seized Tzu-wo and reported it [to the T'ien Clan].
They killed him at Kuo-kuan (Outer City Wall Pass).
Ch'eng Tzu was about to kill Ta-lu Tzu-fang,
[but] T'ien Ni requested that he spare him.
Uder the Duke's orders he [Tzu-fang] took a chariot that was on the road
and went out through Yung-men (Yung Gate).
T'ien Pao gave him a chariot,
[but] he would not accept it from him,
saying,
"[T'ien] Ni made a request for me.
If [T'ien] Pao gives me a chariot,
I would have had secret dealings with you.
I served Tzu-wo, and if I have secret dealings with his foes,
how could I face the gentlemen of Lu and
Wei?"
On the keng-ch'en day (4 May),
T'ien Ch'ang seized Duke Chien at Shu-chou.
The Duke said,
"If I had followed the chariot driver [T'ien] Yang's words earlier,
it would not have reached this."
On the chia-wu day (18 May),
T'ien Ch'ang killed Duke Chien in Shu-chou.
T'ien Ch'ang then invested Duke Chien's younger brother Ao,
and he was Duke P'ing (r. 480–456 B.C.).
When Duke P'ing ascended the throne,
T'ien Ch'ang assisted him
and monopolized the government of Ch'i.
He ceded the land to the east of An-p'ing in Ch'i as the T'ien Clan fief.
In the eighth year of Duke P'ing (473 B.C.),
Yüeh destroyed Wu.
In the twenty-fifth year (456 B.C.), he expired,
and his son, Chi, Duke Hsüan (r. 455–405 B.C.), was invested.
In the fifty-first year of Duke Hsüan (405 B.C.), he expired,
and his son, T'ai, Duke K'ang (r. 404 B.C.), was invested.
T'ien Hui revolted in Lin-ch'iu.
In the second year of Duke K'ang (403 B.C.),
Han, Wei, and
Chao were first ranked as feudal lords.
In the nineteenth year (386 B.C.),
Tien Ch'ang's great grandson, T'ien Ho, first became a feudal lord.
He moved Duke K'ang to the seacoast.
In the twenty-sixth year (379 B.C.),
Duke K'ang expired.
The Lü Clan consequently terminated their ancestral sacrifices.
The T'an Clan finally possessed the state of Ch'i,
making King Wei of Ch'i (r. *378–343 B.C.)
strong in the world.
His Honor the Grand Scribe says:
I have gone to Ch'i.
From Mount T'ai it stretches to Lang-ya,
and spreads north to the sea,
[having] two thousand square li of fertile land.
Its people are open-handed and have much hidden wisdom.
That is their disposition.
It was on the sagaciousness of T'ai-kung
that the foundation of the state was established.
It flourished with Duke Huan, who,
in practicing excellent government policies
and in making the feudal lords assemble at covenants,
claimed Hegemony.
Was this not only fitting?
How wide and vast!
It surely had the style of a great state!
The Duke of Chou and Lu, Hereditary House 3
Tan, the Duke of Chou,
was a younger brother of King Wu of Chou (r. 1049/45–1043 B.C.).
Since the time when King Wen (r. 1042/35–1006 B.C.) was alive,
Tan was filial as a son.
He was sincere and kind,
different from the other sons [of King Wen].
By the time King Wu ascended the throne,
Tan often supported and protected King Wu
and the affairs he had charge of were numerous.
In the ninth year of King Wu,
he moved east and launched a punitive expedition, reaching Meng-chin.
The Duke of Chou assisted him in his action.
In the eleventh year,
[King Wu] launched a punitive expedition against Chow,
reaching Mu-yeh.
The Duke of Chou aided King Wu
in composing "Mu shih" (The Oath at Mu).
They defeated Yin
and entered the Shang palace.
After Chow had been killed,
the Duke of Chou grasped a large halberd,
the Duke of Chao grasped a small halberd,
and stood on each side of King Wu in this manner.
They offered blood sacrifices at the altar of soil
and reported the offenses of Chow to Heaven
as well as to the people of Yin.
They released the Viscount of Chi from prison,
and enfeoffed Wu-keng Lu-fu, the son of Chow,
making the Younger [Prince] of Kuan and
the Younger [Prince] of Ts'ai assist him,
so as to continue the sacrifices of Yin.
[The King] enfeoffed all the meritorious vassals and those relatives who shared his cognomen.
He enfeoffed Tan, the Duke of Chou, at Ch'ü-fu, the ruins of Shao-hao.
This was the Duke of Lu.
The Duke of Chou did not go to take up his fief,
staying to aid King Wu.
Two years after King Wu overcame Yin,
the world was not yet settled.
King Wu had a disease
and was not feeling well.
The numerous vassals were frightened.
T'ai-kung (Our Grandfather)
and the Duke of Chao then respectfully consulted the oracle.
The Duke of Chou said,
"We cannot in this way make our late kings anxious."
Only then did the Duke of Chou make an offering of himself [to the Supreme Deity]
and set up three altars.
The Duke of Chou stood facing north,
grasping a jade disc and holding a jade tablet.
He reported to T'ai-wang (The Great King),
Chi, the King,
and King Wen.
The scribes made an invocation on bamboo slips which read,
"Your chief descendent, Fa, the King,
is diligent and hard-working and is suffering from disease.
If you Three Kings really bear the debt to Heaven for a son [to die],
take me, Tan, in place of the person of Fa, the King.
I, Tan, am smart and able.
I have many talents and many skills
and am able to serve the spirits and deities.
Fa, the King, does not have as many talents and skills as I, Tan,
and is not able to serve the ghosts and spirits.
[Yet] he received an order from the court of the Emperor [of Heaven]
to spread [his way] and help the four quarters,
and thereby he was able to settle your descendants on the earth below.
The peoples of the four quarters all hold him in respect and awe.
Do not let fall the precious mandate which Heaven has sent down,
and our late kings will always have some place to return to.
Now may I receive your orders through the great tortoise.
If you grant my request,
I will return with a jade disc and tablet [for you],
so as to await your orders.
If you do not grant [my request],
I will then put away the jade disc and tablet."

Chi, the King,
and King Wen,

The diviners all said [the results] were auspicious.
They opened the [divine] documents to read them
[and] they were really auspicious.
